### Context: The article titled "Yoga and Stretching Equally Effective for Back Pain" discusses a study that compared the effectiveness of yoga and stretching in treating chronic back pain. The journalist adequately quantified the benefits of both interventions in terms of primary and secondary outcome measures. However, the article did not mention the costs or cost-effectiveness of these interventions, which is an important issue as individuals may have to bear the costs themselves.

The article also did not discuss adverse events in any of the groups, despite the study reporting on them. This is significant because many people with back pain avoid exercise programs due to fear of worsening their symptoms. The study primarily focused on subjects with mild-to-moderate uncomplicated chronic back pain, so it is unclear if the results apply to individuals with more severe back pain.

There was no obvious disease mongering in the article, as chronic back pain is a legitimate concern for the general public. However, the article would have benefited from additional expert input, considering the complexity of the evidence on chronic back pain and the effectiveness of yoga and stretching.

The article did not mention any conflicts-of-interest from the authors of the clinical trial, so there was no need to report on this criterion. While the article mentioned several potential therapies for chronic back pain, it did not discuss a full range of alternative treatments.

The writer assumed that yoga classes and stretching programs are widely available across the United States, but it is not clear if similar programs are accessible in most communities or covered by health insurance plans.

The article did not discuss the novelty of the treatment interventions. The intensive stretching class used in the study appears to be a novel intervention developed specifically for the trial, and similar programs may not be widely available. The "viniyoga" program may be less novel but is still distinctive.

Lastly, the article did not rely on a news release from Group Health in Seattle, which released a lengthy press release on the study. The New York Times article did not appear to use this press release as a source.

In summary, the article adequately described the study and its results but lacked information on costs, adverse events, limitations, expert input, and the availability of the interventions.
Claim: Yoga and Stretching Equally Effective for Back Pain
The claim veracity: mixture

### Explanation:
label: mixture
explanation: An independent expert can point out whether a study is valid and relevant and whether any cautionary notes should accompany its conclusions. The article provided an accurate, bare-bones description of the study and its main conclusions—that yoga and intensive stretching were similarly effective and were both superior to the self-care intervention. But it also missed several key points, as detailed in the scoring below. And since the study in the Archives of Internal Medicine was actually accompanied by an independent commentary that could have been cited, these omissions are all the more telling. So what points might an independent expert have added to the coverage?The most important one is that the subjects in this study were relatively affluent and generally had mild back pain and modest functional limitations. The results of this study may not apply to the large body of patients from less affluent backgrounds with more severe back pain, greater functional impairment, and more complex health problems. Would a roughneck on an oil rig, an auto mechanic, or a hotel maid gain a similar benefit from yoga or intensive stretching as the subjects in this study? No one really knows. The availability of these treatments is also an issue. Similarly structured viniyoga programs may not be available in many communities—and it is not clear that most health insurance plans will cover them. The type of intensive stretching program described in this study would appear to be uncommon in the United States. So most patients wouldn’t have access to this intervention. Lastly, this study did not compare yoga and intensive stretching to “usual care”. So yoga and intensive stretching may be superior to a self-care program, but it is not as clear that they are any better than routine back care as dispensed across the United States. In the United States, back pain is the ninth most expensive medical condition for women, and the 10th for men, in terms of direct medical costs—with chronic back pain accounting for a disproportionate chunk of those expenses. And the costs of work absence and disability claims related to back pain vastly exceed the medical price tag. Though Americans spend almost $35 billion per year on the medical treatment of back pain, the prevalence of chronic back pain appears to be rising—and self-rated spinal health among Americans appears be declining. (See Soni, 2011; Freburger et al., 2008; and Martin et al., 2008). A number of nonsurgical treatments—analgesics, exercise, manual therapies, complementary/alternative therapies, psychological interventions, and multidisciplinary rehabilitation—are modestly effective in the management of chronic back pain. Yet for various reasons, Americans overuse ineffective treatments and underuse effective ones. (See Carey et al., 2009). So the identification of treatments that facilitate recovery and are popular with patients is a key social and medical priority. References for This Review:  Balagué F et al., Non-specific low back pain, Lancet, epub ahead of print, October 7, 2011; DOI:10.1016/S0140- 6736(11)60610-7). Carey TS et al., A long way to go: Practice patterns and evidence in chronic low back pain care, Spine, 2009; 34(7):718–24. Medicine, 2007; 147(7):478– 91. Freburger J et al., The rising prevalence of chronic low back pain, Archives of Internal Medicine, 2009; 169(3):251–8. Martin BI et al. Expenditures and health status among adults with back and neck problems. JAMA 2008; 299:656-664. Soni A, Top ten most costly conditions among men and women, 2008, Agency for Healthcare Quality and Research, Statistical Brief #331, 2011. www.meps.ahrq.gov/mepsweb/data_files/publications/st331/stat331.pdf.

### Context: On September 20, 2019, millions of students and workers around the world participated in a coordinated protest to demand action on climate change. The protests began in the Pacific islands, where rising sea levels pose a threat to their way of life, and spread across Australia, Japan, Southeast Asia, Europe, Africa, the Middle East, and the Americas. The protests culminated in New York City's Wall Street, where massive crowds gathered to hear Greta Thunberg, a prominent figure in the climate movement, speak.

Thunberg, who sailed across the Atlantic in an emissions-free yacht, addressed the crowd and emphasized the importance of taking action. She stated that if others refuse to act, the protesters will continue to make a difference and bring about change. Thunberg has become an icon for the younger generation and has played a significant leadership role in the international movement to reduce fossil fuel consumption.

The protests were not limited to New York City. Demonstrators in Paris raised a painting of Thunberg as the Virgin Mary, symbolizing the urgency of the climate crisis. In Brazil, thousands of people gathered to protest President Jair Bolsonaro's environmental policies, which they believe are contributing to the destruction of the Amazon rainforest. Similar protests took place in Thailand, Germany, Poland, and other countries, with activists using creative methods to draw attention to the issue.

The protests come at a time when concern about climate change is escalating, particularly due to the actions of leaders like U.S. President Donald Trump and Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro, who question the science of climate change and have taken steps to dismantle environmental protections. Trump recently blocked stricter vehicle emissions standards in California, while Bolsonaro has been accused of allowing the destruction of the Amazon rainforest for economic gain.

The global protest movement is putting pressure on governments and companies to respond to the climate crisis. German Chancellor Angela Merkel unveiled a new climate protection package, and Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos pledged to make his company net carbon neutral by 2040. Workers from Google, Amazon, and other technology companies also joined the protests, criticizing their industry for being slow to address climate change.

Overall, the protests demonstrate the widespread concern about the environment and the urgent need for action to combat climate change.
Claim: Inspired by Greta Thunberg, worldwide protest demands climate action.
The claim veracity: true

### Explanation:
label: true
explanation: Millions of young people flooded the streets of cities around the world on Friday to demand political leaders take urgent steps to stop climate change, uniting in a worldwide protest inspired by 16-year-old Swedish activist Greta Thunberg.
claim: Inspired by Greta Thunberg, worldwide protest demands climate action.
generated_result: Climate activist Greta Thunberg joined hundreds of thousands of protesters around the world on Friday to demand immediate action to curb emissions and save the planet from environmental disaster.

### Context: India has banned the sale and import of e-cigarettes, citing concerns about the rising popularity of vaping among young people. The ban has affected users nationwide and has also impacted international companies like Juul Labs Inc and Philip Morris International. Local firms have filed court challenges against the ban. However, a recent protest organized by the Association of Vapers India saw a low turnout, with only about 400 people participating across six cities. Some opponents of the ban feared being targeted by the police. At one protest in New Delhi, several people were seen using vaping devices, including a child holding a poster that read, "I don't want my dad to be a smoker."

The government argues that the ban is necessary to protect people from nicotine addiction and to prevent users from transitioning to tobacco consumption. On the other hand, vapers argue that e-cigarettes help them stay away from more harmful tobacco cigarettes. India has the second-highest number of adult smokers in the world, with 106 million smokers, making it a potentially lucrative market for companies selling both tobacco and vaping products. The government estimates that over 900,000 people die each year in India due to tobacco-related illnesses.

Despite protests and court challenges, an Indian health ministry official stated that there would be no rollback of the ban. Two court challenges in Kolkata, including one by e-cigarette importer Plume Vapour, are currently underway and could potentially impact the enforcement of the ban. Plume Vapour argues that the ban will benefit cigarette companies while putting e-cigarette firms out of business.

A protester in New Delhi expressed concerns about running out of vape refills after stocking up ahead of the ban. They called for regulation rather than a complete ban, stating that "everybody has an addiction."
Claim: No vaping ban U-turn, says Indian official, as protests fizzle.
The claim veracity: true

### Explanation:
label: true
explanation: India’s government has no plan to roll back a ban on electronic cigarettes, an official told Reuters on Saturday, as protests against the move by vapers in six cities drew scant support.
claim: No vaping ban U-turn, says Indian official, as protests fizzle.
generated_result: India’s ban on e-cigarettes will not be rolled back, a health ministry official said on Thursday, as protests against the move fizzled out.

### Context: According to a Reuters/Ipsos poll conducted from March 18-24, U.S. men are taking the coronavirus less seriously than women. The poll, which surveyed nearly 4,500 American adults, found that women are more likely to support aggressive measures to combat the virus and take personal precautions such as avoiding physical contact and washing their hands more frequently. The gender gap is consistent across different races, political affiliations, and community types.

The poll revealed that 54% of women are "very concerned" about the virus, compared to 45% of men. Women are also more likely to make significant changes to their daily routines, with 73% reporting increased handwashing and disinfectant use, compared to 60% of men. Additionally, 72% of women are avoiding large public gatherings, which is 14 percentage points higher than men, and 65% of women are avoiding close physical contact with others, which is 9 points higher than men.

The article suggests that women may be more concerned about the virus because they are often responsible for "kinkeeping," such as checking on the health of parents and grandparents. Women also tend to do more childcare, so the closure of schools has a greater impact on them.

When asked about the actions the U.S. government should take to slow the spread of the virus, women were more likely than men to support aggressive restrictions such as nighttime curfews, bans on public gatherings, and halting public transportation and overseas flights. For example, 58% of women supported closing all public schools, compared to 52% of men.

The poll also found that a significant minority of men are more dismissive of the potential harm of the virus. 25% of men strongly agree that people are "unnecessarily panicking," compared to 18% of women. Men are also more likely to believe that the media is creating panic about something that isn't a big deal for most people.

The article concludes by highlighting personal anecdotes that illustrate the differing attitudes between men and women. Some women have expressed frustration with their partners' lack of concern and failure to take necessary precautions.

Overall, the poll suggests that U.S. men are less likely to heed health warnings and take the coronavirus seriously compared to women.
Claim: U.S. men less likely to heed health warnings as coronavirus death toll mounts: Reuters Poll.
The claim veracity: true

### Explanation:
label: true
explanation: As America converts itself into a nation of shut-ins, one group appears to be less interested than others in following the ever-lengthening list of health tips aimed at slowing the spread of the coronavirus pandemic: men.
claim: U.S. men less likely to heed health warnings as coronavirus death toll mounts: Reuters Poll.
generated_result: A Reuters/Ipsos poll on Wednesday showed U.S. women are more likely than men to take precautions to protect themselves from the coronavirus and are more worried about the virus spreading in their communities.

### Context: A recent article titled "Gene therapy raises hope for a future AIDS cure" discusses a new approach to gene therapy that has shown promising results in treating HIV. The article emphasizes the importance of providing specific details on the trial subjects' cell counts and the timeframe in which changes occurred. However, it also acknowledges that it is too early to determine if these lab results will translate into improvements in patients' lives. The article quotes a member of the conference program committee who states that it is still unknown if there is any antiviral activity resulting from the experiments.

The article mentions that the only side effect observed in the study was two days of flu-like symptoms, but it notes that longer-term safety is still being evaluated. It also highlights the fact that all six patients involved in the study had well-controlled HIV, making it impossible to determine if there would be a therapeutic effect. Additionally, the article points out that another presentation at the same conference revealed that a similar process in mouse research showed a protective effect that wore off over time. The article suggests that including this information would have made the report more comprehensive.

The article emphasizes that the research was published only as a short abstract and presented at a scientific conference, meaning it has not undergone rigorous peer review like a journal article would. It commends the absence of disease mongering in the article and notes that several independent sources were quoted. The article explains that this gene therapy approach is the first to permanently delete a human gene and infuse the altered cells back into patients, as previous attempts focused on adding or suppressing gene activity and were not effective against HIV.

The article concludes by stating that the report is very preliminary and mentions that a second federally-funded study is expected to be released soon. It also highlights that the story did not rely solely on a news release for information.

Overall, the article discusses the potential of gene therapy in treating HIV but emphasizes the need for caution due to the early stage of the research and the lack of long-term data.
Claim: Gene therapy raises hope for a future AIDS cure

label: true

The research was only meant to show that, so far, it seems feasible and safe. A researcher “warned that it would be ‘way overstated’ to suggest that the results so far are a possible cure”  A competing MedPage Today story had this headline: “HIV-Resistant T Cells on Horizon.” That story said that the researchers “cautioned reporters not to use the word “cure” at this early stage. But this AP story still used the word “cure” 12 times. It is possible to report on very preliminary research – even involving only six people – and even on a topic like HIV/AIDS – and to do so in a reasonable way. This story achieved that goal – despite the repeated use of “cure”.
claim: Gene therapy raises hope for a future AIDS cure

The story does a good job of explaining that all six patients involved in the study had well-controlled HIV, making it impossible to determine if there would be a therapeutic effect. The story also does a good job of explaining that the only side effect observed was two days of flu-like symptoms, but that longer-term safety is still being evaluated. The story would have been stronger if it had mentioned that a second federally-funded study is expected to be released soon. ### Context: The article discusses the rumors and misinformation surrounding the death of Beth Chapman, the wife of Duane "Dog" Chapman from the reality TV show "Dog the Bounty Hunter." The claim states that Beth Chapman died in April 2019.

In September 2017, Beth Chapman revealed that she had been diagnosed with Stage 2 throat cancer. She underwent surgery and recovered, with the family announcing in November 2017 that she was cancer-free. However, her cancer returned a year later, and she underwent emergency surgery to clear a throat blockage obstructing her airways.

On April 7, 2019, it was confirmed that Beth Chapman had been hospitalized due to a buildup of fluid in her lungs. Several websites and social media pages created clickbait and rumors about her passing. A YouTube video with a confusing title and thumbnail image generated over 1.5 million views, leading some people to believe that she had died. However, she was hospitalized and later released, as confirmed by a lawyer for the Chapman family.

Despite the rumors, Beth Chapman continued to post updates regularly on social media. On April 14, 2019, she posted a picture of herself on Instagram with the statement, "Don't forget the reason for the season." On April 20, 2019, another misleading article appeared on a website claiming that Beth Chapman had died. However, the article's headline question, "Did Beth Chapman Die from Dog the Bounty Hunter?" was answered misleadingly by referencing a different question from the body of the text.

The article concludes by stating that Beth Chapman did indeed pass away in April 2019. However, it does not provide any further details or information about her death.
Claim: Beth Chapman, wife of Duane “Dog” Chapman from the reality TV show “Dog the Bounty Hunter,” died in April 2019. 
The claim veracity: mixture

### Explanation:
label: mixture
explanation: Because the rumors of her death appear to stem from dubious clickbait websites with misleading or confusing statements, and because Chapman is still active on social media, and because no member or representative of the Chapman family has suggested she lost her battle with cancer, we rank rumors of Beth Chapman’s death as false.
claim: Beth Chapman, wife of Duane “Dog” Chapman from the reality TV show “Dog the Bounty Hunter,” died in April 2019.
generated_result: Did ‘Dog the Bounty Hunter’ Wife Beth Chapman Die in April 2019?

### Context: A study conducted in Washington State's King County, which includes Seattle, found that calorie information on menus influenced dining habits, particularly for women, higher-income individuals, and diners who ate at fast-food chains. The study, funded by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation and published in the American Journal of Public Health, surveyed over 3,000 King County residents who frequented chain restaurants. The research began eight months before the county required restaurants to post calorie information in 2009 and continued for two years after. The study confirmed that posting calorie information led to more people seeing and using it. However, the researchers did not ask how diners utilized the calorie information. 

The study builds on previous research funded by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, which examined receipts from over 7,300 King County restaurant customers. This earlier study found that patrons, especially women, who saw the calorie counts purchased fewer calories compared to those who did not. King County was the second jurisdiction in the United States, after New York City, to implement calorie counts under a menu-labeling law. 

Overall, the findings from this study contribute to the growing body of data on how calorie disclosures on menus can impact dining habits. It suggests that calorie information is more likely to be seen and used by women, higher-income individuals, and those who eat at fast-food chains. Additionally, white, higher-income, and obese customers were more likely to view the calorie information. However, the study does not provide specific details on how diners utilized the calorie information.
Claim: Calorie counts on menus used by women, wealthier diners in Seattle area.
The claim veracity: true

### Explanation:
label: true
explanation: Women, higher-income diners and patrons of fast-food restaurants in the Seattle area are more likely to use restaurant calorie count information, according to survey results published on Tuesday.
claim: Calorie counts on menus used by women, wealthier diners in Seattle area.
generated_result: Calorie counts on menus were more likely to be seen by women, higher-income diners and those who ate at fast-food restaurants, according to a study of a Seattle-area law requiring such information.

### Context: The President of the Democratic Republic of Congo, Felix Tshisekedi, has urged the population to trust first responders and get vaccinated against Ebola. Many people in affected areas have refused vaccinations due to mistrust of first responders and misinformation spread by community leaders. Instead, they turn to traditional healers, whose clinics have contributed to the spread of the disease. Tshisekedi emphasized that Ebola is not an imaginary disease and stated that if people follow instructions, the outbreak could be finished in two or three months. The current Ebola outbreak, which began in August 2018, has seen 1,264 confirmed and probable cases and 814 deaths. It is the second largest outbreak in history, surpassed only by the 2013-2016 outbreak in West Africa. The current outbreak is spreading at its fastest rate yet, with over 100 cases confirmed last week. Tshisekedi also called for the disarmament of militia groups operating in the east, as their presence has complicated the Ebola response. He stated that the time of armed groups is over and urged them to surrender their arms through disarmament programs.
Claim: Ebola is real, Congo president tells skeptical population.
The claim veracity: true

### Explanation:
label: true
explanation: Congolese President Felix Tshisekedi on Tuesday implored people in areas hit by the nation’s worst-ever Ebola outbreak to accept the disease is real and trust health workers.
claim: Ebola is real, Congo president tells skeptical population.
generated_result: Congo’s president urged the public to get vaccinated against Ebola, saying the disease is real and that the country’s health system is overwhelmed.

### Context: The article discusses the potential use of MDMA, commonly known as Ecstasy, as a therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). The claim states that the article does not discuss the cost of the treatment, but mentions that it is given along with intensive therapy. The article also mentions the results of a clinical trial where slightly more than half of the participants reported major reductions in PTSD symptoms. However, the article could have emphasized that the drug is proposed for use as part of an intensive therapy program, with doses given only a few times and under professional supervision. The article acknowledges the potential harms of MDMA but does not provide much information about the nature and quality of the existing studies. It mentions that existing drug treatments for PTSD fail two-thirds of patients and compares the rates of PTSD in US and British soldiers. The article suggests that the Multidisciplinary Association for Psychedelic Studies (MAPS) is funding the clinical trials on which an FDA assessment of MDMA's efficacy will be based, but it could have been more overt about this funding support. The article mentions other drugs and therapies for PTSD but states that they are deemed seriously flawed. It also highlights that the FDA has not yet approved the use of MDMA and that large-scale clinical trials are needed. The article cautions against using the street version of MDMA, called Ecstasy, due to potential harmful contaminants. It mentions that small clinical studies on the impact of MDMA on PTSD have been ongoing for years and that the recent FDA classification of MDMA as a "breakthrough therapy" has put it on a faster track for review. Overall, the article provides information about the potential use of MDMA as a therapy for PTSD but could have provided more details about the cost, nature of the studies, and the stance of experts on the issue.
Claim: Ecstasy could be ‘breakthrough’ therapy for soldiers, others suffering from PTSD
The claim veracity: true

### Explanation:
label: true
explanation: Post-traumatic stress disorder is difficult to treat. Over the course of the past decade, evidence has been accumulating that the compound 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA), better known as ecstasy, may be more effective than current drugs such as Zoloft and Paxil. This story, jump-started by a recent decision by the Food and Drug Administration to classify MDMA as a “breakthrough drug,” which allows it to be evaluated and possibly approved more quickly, offers the reader a well-written account of the evolution of MDMA from a bad actor to a potentially efficacious one. An important element of the narrative is the dominant role of a nonprofit organization, the Multidisciplinary Association for Psychedelic Studies, which is dedicated to ending government bans on psychedelic substances and marijuana and has funded virtually all of the extant research on MDMA’s impact on PTSD sufferers. While the story is well-sourced, the text fails to explore this conflict of interest. It also may land too heavily on the side of “probable” rather than “possible.” The headline—Ecstasy could be “breakthrough” therapy for soldiers, others suffering from PTSD—is worded conditionally but clearly heralds the dawn of a new age. Given the long clinical trial road ahead, despite MDMA’s “breakthrough” status designation, much could change. The substance MDMA may meet all evidentiary challenges and emerge at some point in the future as an effective part of the treatment regimen for PTSD. But drumming up enthusiasm for the drug before it is officially available, as this story may do, runs the risk of sending PTSD sufferers to a less safe—and certainly illegal—form: Ecstasy.
claim: Ecstasy could be ‘breakthrough’ therapy for soldiers, others suffering from PTSD
generated_result: The story does a good job of explaining the potential harms of MDMA, and of cautioning readers not to try the street version of the drug, known as Ecstasy. The story could have been more clear about the nature and quality of the existing studies, and about the fact that the FDA has not yet approved the use of MDMA. The story also could have been more overt about the fact that the Multidisciplinary Association for Psychedelic Studies (MAPS) is funding the clinical trials on which an FDA assessment of MDMA’s efficacy will be based. The story also could have been more clear about the fact that the story is reporting on a recent development, the FDA’s classification of MDMA as a “breakthrough therapy,” which has put it on a faster track for review. The story does a good job of explaining the results of a clinical trial, and of emphasizing that the drug is proposed for use as part of an intensive therapy program, with doses given only a few times and under professional supervision. The story could have emphasized that the rates of reduction in PTSD symptoms reported in the story are those of a small number of patients in a clinical trial. The story also could have been more clear about the fact that the results of the clinical trials are not yet conclusive. The story does a good job of explaining the nature of PTSD, and of emphasizing that the drug is proposed for use in patients who have not responded to other treatments. The story could have discussed the cost of the treatment.

### Context: The claim that Event 201 gave out stuffed souvenir coronavirus toys to commemorate the Novel coronavirus outbreak is false. The toy in question is actually a plushie representing a microbe, and it was distributed two months before the first cases of the current coronavirus outbreak appeared. Event 201, organized by the John Hopkins Center for Health Security, the World Economic Forum, and the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, was a simulation exercise held in October 2019 to plan for a global pandemic. The scenario simulated a novel zoonotic coronavirus transmitted from bats to pigs to humans, leading to a severe pandemic. The purpose of the event was to bring together business, government, and public health leaders to inform cooperation for pandemic preparedness and response.

The plushie toys were given out as part of the registration for the event, which aimed to prepare for a new coronavirus pandemic based on the history of previous outbreaks. They were not intended to commemorate the toll that the actual outbreak would bring. The John Hopkins Center for Health Security tweeted a picture of the stuffed microbe as part of its Event 201 registration drive, encouraging people to register for the virtual pandemic exercise.

The organizers of Event 201 did not have insider knowledge about the current coronavirus outbreak. They explicitly stated that the scenario they simulated was not a prediction of the outbreak. The purpose of the simulation was to address the need for pandemic preparedness and response, as there are an average of 200 epidemics that occur annually.

In conclusion, the claim that Event 201 gave out stuffed souvenir coronavirus toys to commemorate the Novel coronavirus outbreak is false. The plushie toys were meant to represent a microbe and were distributed as part of the registration for the event, which aimed to prepare for a new coronavirus pandemic based on historical outbreaks. The organizers did not have insider knowledge about the current outbreak and explicitly stated that their simulation was not a prediction.
Claim: Event 201 “gave out stuffed souvenir coronavirus toys” to “commemorate” Novel coronavirus outbreak
The claim veracity: false

### Explanation:
label: false
explanation: The toy at the center of the controversy is supposed to be a coronavirus microbe. Event 201 offered the plushies to people who registered to attend an October 2019 gathering that was designed to help plan for a global pandemic by bringing together business, government, and public health leaders. Event 201 used a fictionalized coronavirus outbreak as its pandemic scenario but did not "predict" the outbreak of a strain that would be detected two months later in December 2019 in Wuhan, China. Microbe plushies representing a number of diseases are widely available for sale. The Event 201 plushies were not intended to commemorate the toll that the coming outbreak would bring.
claim: Event 201 “gave out stuffed souvenir coronavirus toys” to “commemorate” Novel coronavirus outbreak
generated_result: Did Event 201 Give Out Stuffed Souvenir Coronavirus Toys?

### Context: The article confirms that the claim made by Robert Reich, former Labor Secretary under President Bill Clinton, is essentially correct. The article analyzed statistics from the Bureau of Economic Analysis and found that the ratio of corporate profits to wages in 2010 was higher than any year back to at least 1929. The next highest ratio was in 2006. The article also looked at total compensation and found that the ratio in 2010 was matched or exceeded in only four years. The article further states that the ratio has continued to rise in the last six quarters. 

The article explains that the ratio can rise either because corporate profits rise or because wages stagnate. In the case of 2010 and 2011, both of these developments have happened simultaneously, leading to the sudden increase in the ratio. The article suggests that businesses are reluctant to invest their profits due to economic uncertainty and the threat of more taxes and regulations. However, the general pattern of the ratio following other recent recessions suggests that businesses tend to gain ground faster than workers during the recovery phase, pushing the ratio higher. 

The article concludes that while the current increase in the ratio may be temporary, Reich's claim is factually supportable. The article also commends Reich for not over-promising on what the data indicate and giving an appropriately cautious interpretation. The article suggests that once a strong recovery is underway and labor markets return to normal, total labor compensation tends to rise rapidly relative to total income.
Claim: The ratio of corporate profits to wages is now higher than at any time since just before the Great Depression.
The claim veracity: true

### Explanation:
label: true
explanation: Robert Reich says ratio of corporate profits to wages is highest since before Great Depression
claim: The ratio of corporate profits to wages is now higher than at any time since just before the Great Depression.
generated_result: Robert Reich says the ratio of corporate profits to wages is at a 70-year high

### Context: Data compiled by the United Nations (UN) shows slow progress and even regression in child wasting, stunting, and other malnutrition-related issues in the Asia-Pacific region. Despite economic growth, worsening inequality means that incomes are not increasing fast enough to ensure adequate nutrition for the millions still living in poverty. The UN report calls for governments to combine efforts to end poverty and implement nutrition, health, and education-oriented policies. The UN's sustainable development goals for 2030 aim to end hunger and ensure access to food throughout the year for all people. However, progress in reducing undernourishment has slowed in recent years.

In the Asia-Pacific region, over a fifth of the population faces moderate to severe food insecurity, meaning they must scrimp on food or go hungry for part of the year, and in extreme cases, go days without eating. South Asia has over half of the 479 million undernourished people in the region, with more than a third of children suffering from chronic malnutrition. India has a particularly acute form of malnutrition, with nearly 21% of children suffering from wasting.

The report emphasizes that failing to ensure children are well-nourished jeopardizes their future development, especially their cognitive abilities. Cognitive abilities are crucial in the 21st century age of advanced technologies, and investing in the first 1,000 days of a child's life is the most important investment for future productivity.

Some governments in the region have begun implementing policies to address the severe shortfalls in child and maternal nutrition. Thailand has provided subsidies to improve the health and diets of families with young children. Myanmar is expanding trial programs to cover more of the country, focusing on improving awareness about nutrition, family planning, and water and sanitation. Cambodia is expanding a program called NOURISH, which provides assistance to impoverished pregnant women and families during the first 1,000 days of a baby's life. The program has shown a nearly 20% decrease in stunting and improved toddlers' diets.

While many in Asia still do not receive enough calories to thrive, the Pacific islands face the opposite problem of too many empty calories. Obesity rates in the Pacific islands are among the highest in the world, partly due to the high cost and limited availability of healthy foods, as well as cultural emphasis on feasting.

Overall, the UN report highlights the urgent need for action to address hunger and malnutrition in the Asia-Pacific region, particularly among children. Governments are urged to implement comprehensive policies that combine efforts to end poverty with nutrition, health, and education-oriented initiatives.
Claim: UN: Nearly a half-billion in Asia-Pacific still going hungry.
The claim veracity: true

label: true

### Context: Senator Dick Durbin claimed that President Obama's Supreme Court nominees, Elena Kagan and Sonia Sotomayor, met a standard of 60 votes. However, this claim oversimplifies the process for Senate votes on Supreme Court nominees. While a formal confirmation vote does not require 60 votes, a successful cloture vote, which places a time limit on the consideration of a nominee, does require 60 votes. The confirmation process for Supreme Court nominees involves a hearing before the Senate Judiciary Committee, referral to the full Senate, and a vote by the full Senate. If unanimous consent cannot be reached, and if at least one senator filibusters, the Senate majority leader would need to invoke cloture, which requires 60 votes. After the cloture vote, there is additional debate time before a final confirmation vote. The rule change in 2013 eliminated the 60-vote threshold for most nominations, but Supreme Court nominees were excluded from this change. Some Democrats have threatened to filibuster the nomination of Neil Gorsuch, which would require 60 votes to invoke cloture. Currently, Republicans hold 52 seats in the Senate, which is enough to reach the final vote threshold of 51 votes if they can get that far. Durbin's claim that Kagan and Sotomayor met a standard of 60 votes is misleading because the nominations were never filibustered, and the final confirmation only required 51 votes. The existing Senate "standard" does not specify reaching 60 votes. Durbin's claim is therefore rated as misleading.
Claim: Richard Durbin Says President Barack Obama’s nominees met a standard of 60 votes, "a standard that was met by Elena Kagan as well as Sonia Sotomayor, President Obama's choices.
The claim veracity: mixture

### Explanation:
label: mixture
explanation: In an interview on MSNBC’s Morning Joe show, Durbin said Obama’s nominees met a standard of 60 votes, "a standard that was met by Elena Kagan as well as Sonia Sotomayor, President Obama's choices." Obama’s nominees cleared the procedural hurdles and won 60 votes and then some. The Senate confirmed Kagan by a roll call vote of 63-37 in 2010, and Sotomayor was confirmed in 2009 by a vote of 68-31. Kagan and Sotomayor ultimately would have had enough votes to be able to break a filibuster, but they never had to -- and the margins they got on the final, simple-majority vote can’t be used to retroactively define what the "standard" was.
claim: Richard Durbin Says President Barack Obama’s nominees met a standard of 60 votes, "a standard that was met by Elena Kagan as well as Sonia Sotomayor, President Obama's choices.
generated_result: Durbin said President Obama’s Supreme Court nominees, Elena Kagan and Sonia Sotomayor, ""met a standard of 60 votes."" Durbin’s claim is misleading. The nominations were never filibustered, and the final confirmation only required 51 votes. The existing Senate ""standard"" does not specify reaching 60 votes. Durbin’s claim is therefore rated False. Correction: This story was updated to clarify that the 60-vote threshold for Supreme Court nominees was not a new rule, but rather a longstanding tradition.

### Context: President Donald Trump has claimed that the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) is the "biggest trade deal ever made." However, this claim is not entirely accurate. While the USMCA is a significant trade agreement, it is not a completely new deal but rather an update to the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), which has been in place since 1994.

The USMCA introduces several changes, particularly in the auto industry and intellectual property protection. It also addresses issues related to the Canadian dairy market and implements new labor and environmental standards. However, it is important to note that the USMCA is building off of NAFTA and is not a trade agreement from scratch.

Furthermore, there are larger trade pacts across the world that surpass the USMCA in terms of the number of countries involved and economic output. For example, in 2018, the European Union signed a trade agreement with Japan, covering a quarter of the global economy and 600 million people. Additionally, the Trans-Pacific Partnership, which included the same three USMCA partners along with nine other Pacific Rim countries, would have represented nations with 40% of global gross domestic product. However, Trump withdrew the United States from this agreement.

The USMCA is significant for the United States alone, as total U.S. trade with Canada and Mexico under NAFTA is the largest of any U.S. free trade partners. Canada and Mexico account for about 30% of U.S. goods exports and imports. However, in terms of the number of countries involved and economic output, there are other trade deals that surpass the USMCA.

In conclusion, while President Trump claims that the USMCA is the "biggest trade deal ever made," this is an overreach. The USMCA is an update to NAFTA and introduces changes in various areas. While it is significant for the United States, there are larger trade pacts globally in terms of the number of countries involved and economic output.
Claim: Donald Trump Says the USMCA is the “biggest trade deal ever made.”
The claim veracity: false

### Explanation:
label: false
explanation: The USMCA, which replaces NAFTA, is the largest trade multilateral agreement signed by the United States. But there have been bigger trade deals around the world, notably a deal between the European Union and Japan, which covers 600 million people.
claim: Donald Trump Says the USMCA is the “biggest trade deal ever made.”
generated_result: The USMCA is a significant trade deal for the United States, but it’s not the biggest trade deal ever made.

### Context: A blood test may be able to identify the risk of gestational diabetes in the first trimester of pregnancy, according to a new study. The study, funded by the National Institutes of Health (NIH), found that each 0.1 percent increase in HbA1c levels above 5.1 percent in early pregnancy was associated with a 22 percent higher risk for gestational diabetes. However, the release notes that the test is not currently recommended to diagnose gestational diabetes at any point in pregnancy and more research is needed to prove the association identified in the study. The blood test itself is considered harmless and fairly reliable, but results can be affected by unrelated diseases and lifestyle factors, leading to false positives and negatives. The release does not provide information about the population of women studied, such as age, race, number of pregnancies, socioeconomic status, and comorbidities. The cost of A1C screening for gestational diabetes is estimated to be between $12 and $65, and the glucose tolerance test given later in pregnancy has an average cost of $60 to $85. The release does not provide specific cost information for the blood test in question. The potential benefits of screening for gestational diabetes include substantial savings in healthcare costs. However, the release does not provide data about the frequency of the disorder. The release emphasizes that the test is not currently recommended for clinical screening and is far from ready for use in diagnosing gestational diabetes. The test has theoretical potential to determine early risk and the potential for lifestyle changes to modify that risk. Overall, the release is considered satisfactory, as it quantifies the results and potential benefits, acknowledges the limitations of the study, and highlights the need for further research.
Claim: Blood test may identify gestational diabetes risk in first trimester
The claim veracity: true

### Explanation:
label: true
explanation: This release accurately describes an observational study using second-hand data from another study  which found that a relatively inexpensive blood test (HbA1c or A1C for short), commonly used to monitor diabetes, might help identify women at risk for getting gestational diabetes as early as the 10th week of pregnancy. The release does a good job of explaining that the disorder carries risks — including the development of adult type 2 diabetes long after birth — for both pregnant women and their newborns. The release notes that the study does not scientifically demonstrate that measuring HbA1c levels in early pregnancy can in fact determine a woman’s later risk for gestational diabetes. On the down side, the release doesn’t mention what it would cost in dollars or potential over treatment to screen every women in the early weeks of pregnancy;  offers no information about the overall prevalence and incidence of gestational diabetes or any details about the women whose records were studied; and waits until the last sentence to note that there also is no firm evidence that lowering HbA1c levels with diet and exercise before or in early pregnancy will actually reduce risk for gestational diabetes. Public health and obstetrical associations estimate that 1 to 15% of all pregnant women in the U.S. develop gestational diabetes and no doubt a greater percentage worries they might. There are potentially serious health consequences to gestational diabetes for mother and child and although some mothers at higher than usual risk — for example, women with obesity — are screened early, most women have a screening blood glucose test later in pregnancy. Glucose and insulin levels are complicated to interpret later in pregnancy. The notion that earlier detection with a test that measures average  glucose levels over time might lead to lowered rates of the disorder is seductive. But it’s also true that such a scenario is only speculation at this time. As a consequence, news releases about this topic are of fairly wide interest, but must be careful not to over promise.
claim: Blood test may identify gestational diabetes risk in first trimester
generated_result: This news release describes a study that found a correlation between a woman’s A1C level in the first trimester of pregnancy and her risk of developing gestational diabetes. The release does a good job of explaining the study and its findings, and of making clear that the test in question is not yet ready for clinical use. The release would have been stronger had it included some cost information, and it would have been stronger still had it included some data about the frequency of gestational diabetes. The release also would have been stronger had it included some information about the women who were studied, such as age, race, number of pregnancies, socioeconomic status and comorbidities. Gestational diabetes is a condition in which a woman develops high blood sugar during pregnancy that resolves after the baby is born. It is estimated to affect 18% of pregnant women in the U.S. The condition can lead to complications for both the mother and the baby. A blood test that could identify women at risk of developing gestational diabetes would be a boon to public health.

With the aging of the US population, especially considering the crush of baby boomers, the subject of how best to manage the pain and disability seen with osteoarthritis of the knee becomes important. While viscosupplementation has been available for many years, the majority of randomized clinical trials have not demonstrated a consistent or important benefit to either pain level or functionality from this therapy. A terse, vaguely worded and incomplete release does little to inform either the general public or the clinical community.

Chafee was referring to Schilling's role in a controversial state economic development deal that would give his video game company, 38 Studios, a $75-million loan guarantee if he moved it to Rhode Island. Chafee criticized the agreement for risking more than half of a new state loan guarantee program on a company that had never generated any revenue. However, Chafee's comments about Schilling's teammates not liking him and painting his bloody sock were seen as disrespectful to the Red Sox player who helped end the team's 86-year championship drought in 2004.

Chafee's campaign quickly retracted the comments, stating that they were intended as an off-hand reference to published reports about the bloody sock and that Chafee respected Schilling's achievements as a professional athlete and his support of charitable causes. The campaign emphasized that Chafee's main concern was protecting the interests of Rhode Island taxpayers.

The article then delves into the history of the rumor that Schilling's bloody sock was actually painted. The rumor originated in 2007 when Baltimore Orioles TV announcer Gary Thorne claimed that Boston's then-backup catcher Doug Mirabelli told him it was a hoax. However, Thorne later apologized, stating that Mirabelli had told him he was joking. The rumor has resurfaced from time to time but has never gained much traction.

The article concludes by stating that all indications suggest that the blood on Schilling's sock was real and that Chafee was wrong in his comments. Chafee's campaign spokesperson acknowledged the mistake and compared it to shooting themselves in the foot. The article criticizes Chafee for the error in the public relations department.

Overall, the article highlights Chafee's criticism of Schilling and the controversy surrounding the rumor that Schilling's bloody sock was painted. It concludes that Chafee was incorrect in his comments and emphasizes the significance of the bloody sock in Red Sox history.
Claim: I remember one of [Curt Schilling's] teammates said he painted his sock, the bloody sock.
The claim veracity: false

label: false
explanation: Chafee says Schilling teammate thought he faked bloody sock
claim: I remember one of [Curt Schilling's] teammates said he painted his sock, the bloody sock.

### Context: The article discusses a study published in JAMA that suggests ultrasound can be an effective additional screening tool for women with dense breast tissue. The broadcast mentioned in the claim highlights the cost issue of insurance payments not covering the full cost of performing and interpreting breast ultrasounds. Medicare reimbursement for breast ultrasound is $85, which is insufficient to cover the costs. The same cost problem applies to mammography, as hospitals lose money on every mammogram they perform.

The article mentions that the addition of ultrasound to mammography detected about 4 additional cancers per 1000 women. It also states that 49% of cancers were detected by mammogram alone, while 78% were detected by mammography plus ultrasound. However, the broadcast does not provide this important absolute data.

The potential harms of treatment, such as false positives, unnecessary biopsies, and anxiety, are mentioned in the story. False positives may decrease with additional screening methods like MRI or annual ultrasound. The high rate of false positives with mammography plus ultrasound means that only about 1 in 10 women with suspected cancer on combined screening actually had cancer when biopsy was done, compared to 1 in 5 women with abnormal mammograms alone.

The study discussed in the broadcast is one of the few large-scale randomized controlled trials evaluating ultrasound as an additional screening method for women with dense breasts. However, the story does not adequately discuss the study design or provide context and in-depth analysis.

The broadcast does not engage in disease mongering and focuses on the review of the JAMA paper. It mentions that ultrasound may find more early-stage cancers in women with dense breast tissue, who may be at higher risk and may be missed by traditional screening methods.

The story lacks independent expert perspective, as the only physician or expert interviewed only commented on how ultrasound works, not on the findings of the study. The story also mentions MRI as a supplemental screening method for women at very high risk and breast biopsy if there is a suspicion of cancer. It emphasizes the need to tailor screening to a woman's individual risk profile and preferred screening schedule.

The availability of properly trained physicians and technicians can vary in real-world clinical settings, potentially affecting the accuracy of ultrasound screening. The study provides good evidence of the value of ultrasound as an additional screening tool, but the story does not mention that ultrasound is already available and not a new method of treatment.

Overall, the article highlights the cost issue of insurance payments, the benefits and potential harms of ultrasound as an additional screening tool, the study design, the lack of independent expert perspective, and the need for tailored screening based on individual risk profiles.

Ultrasound is already available, as implied in the story, and not a new method of treatment. The broadcast does not mention that physicians and ultrasonographers in the study were trained using standardized screening protocols. In a real-world clinical setting, the availability of properly training physicians and technicians can vary, resulting in greater false-negatives or false-positives. The editorial by Dr. Kulk accompanying the JAMA source article states, "It is questionable whether the diagnostic accuracy achieved in the study..would have been the same if nonradiologists had performed screening ultrasound." The story could have mentioned this. In addition, the story didn’t discuss costs, didn’t explain why this study was "the most definitive so far," and didn’t explain benefits in absolute terms which are probably most helpful to most viewers. Importantly, the story mentions that screening may need to be tailored to a woman’s individual risk profile, as well as her preferred screening schedule based on an assessment of risks and benefits.

### Context: Ohio Governor Mike DeWine has outlined his priorities for 2020 in a recent interview. One of his main focuses is improving mental health care in the state, as he believes Ohio is currently lacking in this area. DeWine wants to ensure that those with mental health issues have access to help as early as possible.

Another important issue for DeWine is the opioid crisis. He has convened a working group to determine how any settlement dollars from lawsuits against drugmakers should be spent. DeWine believes that the money should be used to address addiction problems.

DeWine has also expressed concern about the high rate of assault against juvenile offenders in Ohio's youth prisons. He has ordered his director of youth prisons to investigate the issue and report back to him. DeWine wants to implement real-time monitoring of abuse allegations to ensure the safety of incarcerated individuals.

When it comes to politics, DeWine declined to comment on the impeachment proceedings against President Donald Trump. However, he believes that his administration's efforts at bipartisan compromise in politically divided Ohio should inspire faith that politicians can work together.

DeWine is optimistic that a package of gun-law changes will eventually pass through the Legislature. He believes that the stalled proposal will eventually be approved, despite facing resistance from the Republican-controlled Legislature.

On the topic of abortion, DeWine did not discuss whether he would sign a bill that included a description of a medically impossible procedure for reimplanting ectopic pregnancies. He wants to focus on the legal fate of legislation that bans abortions after the first fetal heartbeat. DeWine stated that he is not taking positions on other pending abortion legislation at this time.

DeWine also highlighted his achievements in his first year as governor, including passing a gas-tax increase and a compromise state budget that allocated funding for mental health and children's programs. He also cut income taxes for low-wage earners with support from both parties.

Overall, DeWine's agenda for 2020 includes improving mental health care, addressing the opioid crisis, ensuring the safety of incarcerated individuals, promoting bipartisan cooperation, passing gun-law changes, and monitoring the legal fate of abortion legislation.
Claim: Foster care, mental health, guns on DeWine’s 2020 agenda.
The claim veracity: true

label: true
explanation: Ohio Gov. Mike DeWine will soon propose “rather dramatic changes” to the foster care system and significant additional investment in mental health programs, he said Friday.
claim: Foster care, mental health, guns on DeWine’s 2020 agenda.
generated_result: Ohio Gov. Mike DeWine said Wednesday he’s focused on improving mental health care, addressing the state’s opioid crisis and ensuring the safety of incarcerated youth.

### Context: The World Health Organization (WHO) is set to reconvene its Emergency Committee to determine if the rapid spread of the new coronavirus from China constitutes a global emergency. The virus has spread to 15 countries, with over 6,000 cases reported worldwide, the majority of which are in China. All deaths so far have occurred in China, with 132 fatalities reported as of Tuesday. Chinese President Xi Jinping described the situation as "grim and complex." The WHO's panel of experts will reassess the situation on Thursday. The organization praised China's response to the outbreak, stating that they are taking extraordinary measures. Major airlines have suspended flights to China, and there are predictions of a significant impact on economic growth. In many Chinese cities, streets are deserted, tourist attractions are closed, and Starbucks coffee shops are requiring temperature checks and mask-wearing. The virus has primarily affected the central province of Hubei, which is under virtual lockdown. The virus originated in a live wild animal market in the provincial capital Wuhan. Several governments, including the United States, France, and Britain, are evacuating their citizens from Wuhan. The virus is having a significant impact on China's economy, with companies cutting corporate travel and tourists canceling trips. Various airlines are reducing flights, and Hong Kong stocks have taken a hit. However, scientists in Australia have developed a lab-grown version of the virus, which could potentially lead to the development of a vaccine. The number of cases in China has surpassed the 5,327 cases of the Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) outbreak in 2002-2003. While the new strain, known as "2019-nCoV," may not be as deadly as SARS, concerns have grown due to its rapid spread and unknown attributes. The virus is transmitted through droplets from coughs and sneezes, with an incubation period of one to 14 days.
Claim: WHO to reconsider declaring global emergency as China virus evacuations begin.
The claim veracity: true

### Explanation:
label: true
explanation: Foreign governments flew their citizens out of the epicentre of China’s coronavirus outbreak on Wednesday, as the number of deaths jumped to 133 and the World Health Organization voiced “grave concern” about person-to-person spread in three other countries.
claim: WHO to reconsider declaring global emergency as China virus evacuations begin.
generated_result: The World Health Organization (WHO) said on Tuesday it would reconvene its Emergency Committee to decide whether the rapid spread of a new coronavirus from China to 15 other countries and territories constitutes a global emergency.

### Context: Republican National Committee chairman Reince Priebus defended the 2016 Republican Party platform, which many observers have said leans to the right on social issues. In an interview with NBC’s Chuck Todd, Priebus was asked about the platform’s position on same-sex marriage. He referenced a draft that claims "the data, the facts lead to an inescapable conclusion that every child deserves a married mom and dad" based on the belief that children raised in a traditional household are healthier and less likely to engage in crime and substance abuse. Priebus stated that while it is possible for children of same-sex parents and single parents to have successful lives, the best scenario is for children to grow up in a traditional opposite-sex household.

However, scholarly research shows that the claim made by Priebus is not supported by the evidence. Researchers at Columbia Law School reviewed 78 scholarly articles on the well-being of children living with gay or lesbian parents over the past three decades. Of those articles, 74 concluded that children of same-sex parents fare no worse than children of opposite-sex parents. The remaining four articles that argue children face more risks with opposite-sex parents than they do with same-sex parents are considered problematic because most of the child subjects grew up with opposite-sex parents but one of the parents eventually came out as gay or lesbian, causing family breakup or turmoil.

Gary Gates, an expert in LGBT demography at the University of California Los Angeles, states that studies comparing children in long-term intact families with same-sex couple parents show that they generally do as well as kids in long-term intact families with different-sex parents. Gates co-authored an overview of contemporary research about LGBT parents, which found that LGBT parents and their children are doing well. However, research in this area faces challenges such as obtaining a large and diverse sample size and studying subcategories like sibling dynamics among children with same-sex parent families or domestic violence.

Overall, the scholarly consensus is that what matters to children is the quality and stability of the parenting, rather than the parents’ particular sex, gender, or sexual orientation. The claim made by Priebus that "the best scenario for kids is a loving mom and dad" is not supported by scholarly data.
Claim: What the facts say" is ... "the best scenario for kids is a loving mom and dad.
The claim veracity: false

### Explanation:
label: false
explanation: Priebus said, "What the facts say" is ... "the best scenario for kids is a loving mom and dad,"  as opposed to having same-sex parents. The limited pieces of research that appear to support Priebus’ claim have been called into question. And overall, scholarly research shows that what matters to children is the quality and stability of the parenting, rather than the parents’ particular sex, gender or sexual orientation.
claim: What the facts say" is ... "the best scenario for kids is a loving mom and dad.
generated_result: Priebus said, ""What the facts say is that the best scenario for kids is a loving mom and dad."" Scholarly data says otherwise. The consensus among social scientists is that what matters to children is the quality and stability of the parenting, not the parents’ particular sex, gender or sexual orientation. Priebus’s claim is not supported by the scholarly data.

### Context: Kansas Governor Laura Kelly discussed the ongoing problems at Osawatomie State Hospital, stating that the 60-bed Adair Acute Care unit is too small to accommodate patients with serious mental health issues. The facility has faced issues since January 2016 when it was decertified by the federal Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services due to security and safety concerns. This led to the loss of millions of dollars in federal funds. In December 2017, the Adair portion of the facility was re-certified, allowing it to receive Medicare funding for the 60 beds. However, federal inspectors found that treatment for some patients needed to be more frequent and intense, and there were missing treatment notes and plans without specific goals.

The Kansas Department for Aging and Disability Services, which oversees state hospitals, is working on improvement plans to address these issues. The department has filed a plan to provide more individualized treatment for patients and is also considering crisis centers as a way to improve the state's mental health care system. A law signed in 2017 allows these centers to involuntarily admit individuals for up to 72 hours, and last year, lawmakers approved $2.6 million for mental health care improvements, including funding for the centers.

Governor Kelly believes that investing in crisis centers makes more sense than adding capacity to state mental health hospitals. The Kansas Department for Aging and Disability Services plans to lift the moratorium on new admissions to Osawatomie, which has been in place for years. The agency also aims to focus on providing care near patients' homes and communities.

More detailed information about the plans and budget proposals will be released when Governor Kelly presents her proposed budget later this month. The Kansas Department for Aging and Disability Services spokesperson, Cara Sloan-Ramos, confirmed that the agency will include a plan to lift the moratorium on new admissions to Osawatomie and continue focusing on providing care in patients' local areas.
Claim: Gov. Kelly:  Kansas psychiatric hospital unit needs changes.
The claim veracity: true

### Explanation:
label: true
explanation: Kansas Gov. Laura Kelly says a troubled unit within a state hospital for the mentally ill is “not a therapeutic environment” and promised changes.
claim: Gov. Kelly:  Kansas psychiatric hospital unit needs changes.
generated_result: Kansas Gov. Laura Kelly said Wednesday that the state’s largest psychiatric hospital needs changes to its care, but she did not say whether she would lift a moratorium on new admissions to the facility.

The rumor originated from a blog post by Benjamin Fulford, who had previously claimed that the Japanese government was trying to kill him. The post was further aggregated by dubious websites. The blog post claimed that Obama was in custody of the US military police and had informed on his drug dealing bosses. It also mentioned the impoundment of an airplane filled with Afghan Heroin and North Korean amphetamines at Argyle International Airport in the Caribbean, which was intended to finance the operations of Daesh (ISIS). The post also referenced a conspiracy site's report about Obama fleeing the scene of a drug bust on a fishing vessel named the Lady Michelle in the Caribbean.

However, none of these claims are true. The story originated from a fake news conspiracy site called WhatDoesItMean.com, known for publishing sensational and false reports. The site's alleged author, Sorcha Faal, is known for creating reports with sensational headlines and quotes from supposed high-level Russian sources. The image used in the article was taken from a news report about a U.S. Coast Guard drug bust off the coast of Suriname, which had no connection to Obama or Japan.

In summary, the claim that Obama was arrested in Japan in connection with a cocaine seizure on his yacht is false. The rumor originated from a fake news conspiracy site and has no basis in reality.

The claim veracity: false

label: false

claim: President Obama was arrested in Japan in connection with the seizure of massive amounts of cocaine on his yacht.
generated_result: WhatDoesItMean.com is a fake news site that has a history of publishing sensationalized and fabricated reports.

### Context: Costs were reported. And the dyes used to enhance the images cause kidney damage in a significant portion of people.” Clear, succinct summary of the evidence. No disease mongering. An author of the paper, and the author of an accompanying editorial were quoted. The story ends with the researcher saying “doctors should focus on patients’ lifestyle and traditional risk factors such as smoking and obesity.” The story was clear that the scans are not currently recommended by guidelines but that “there have been several reports of doctors doing CCTA heart scans in healthy patients, although the practice is currently discouraged by the American Heart Association.” The relative novelty of the screening test could be deduced from the story. It’s clear that the story did not rely on a news release.
Claim: Heart scans tied to “evidence-free” treatment: study
The claim veracity: true

### Explanation:
label: true
explanation: This story summarized the study and its significance clearly in the first sentence – “When symptom-free people have heart scans to look for clogged arteries, they can end up with overtreatment and side effects.”  The story delivered powerful quotes from experts to put the findings into context for readers:  “Testing might lead to more harm than good.”   “With these new imaging techniques, we are left with the dilemma of what to do with the results.”   “Overdiagnosis is threatening to become an increasingly important public health problem because of the enthusiasm for and proliferation of uNPRoven screening tests.”

### Context: A study conducted in Sweden found that higher levels of folic acid in teenagers' blood were associated with better school grades. The study included 386 teenagers between the ages of 15 and 16, and their folic acid levels were measured through blood samples. The researchers divided the participants into three groups based on their folic acid levels: low, medium, and high.

The study found that the teenagers in the high folic acid group had significantly higher grades compared to those in the low folic acid group. On average, the high folic acid group had a grade point average (GPA) that was 0.4 higher than the low folic acid group. The researchers also took into account other factors that could affect academic performance, such as socioeconomic status and parents' education level.

The study did not establish a cause-and-effect relationship between folic acid levels and grades, but it suggests that folic acid may play a role in cognitive function. Folic acid is known to be important for brain development and function, and previous research has shown that folic acid deficiency during pregnancy can lead to cognitive impairments in children.

It is worth noting that the study had some limitations. It was a small study conducted in Sweden, where the food supply is not fortified with folic acid like it is in the United States. The study also did not account for other potential differences between the groups of teenagers with high and low folic acid levels.

Experts not involved in the study commented on the findings, highlighting the importance of a balanced diet and adequate nutrient intake for overall health and cognitive function. They also emphasized the need for further research to better understand the relationship between folic acid and academic performance.

In conclusion, this study suggests that higher levels of folic acid in teenagers' blood may be associated with better school grades. However, more research is needed to establish a causal relationship and to understand the potential mechanisms behind this association.
Claim: Folic acid tied to better grades in Swedish teens
The claim veracity: true

### Explanation:
label: true
explanation: This is a story about a recent study published in the journal Pediatrics which found an association between folic acid levels and school grades in a cohort of Swedish teens. This story did a reasonable job of describing this cohort study. It explained that the small study may not be meaningful in the US where many common foods are fortified with folic acid – making it unlikely that there are children with low or marginal intakes of this B vitamin. Understanding how to interpret study results and knowing the appropriate questions to ask in order to understand how those results might be applicable is a valuable skill. Helping people think about studies of nutrition in context and whether they might apply to other populations is important. This story demonstrated those skills.
claim: Folic acid tied to better grades in Swedish teens
generated_result: This story reports on a small study that found a correlation between folic acid levels and academic performance in Swedish teens. The story does a good job of explaining the study’s limitations and of pointing out that the study did not prove that folic acid supplementation would improve academic performance. However, the story should have been more clear about the fact that the study was conducted in a country where the food supply is not fortified with folic acid, as it is in the U.S. This is an important detail that could have helped readers understand the study’s limitations. The story also should have been more clear about the fact that the study did not prove that folic acid supplementation would improve academic performance.

### Context: The article discusses a viral social media post that circulated in January 2020, claiming to be an "emergency notification" from an unspecified "Ministry of Health" about the ongoing outbreak of a new coronavirus. The warning appeared in two forms: a text post and a photograph of a printed email. Both versions emphasized the importance of keeping the throat moist to prevent the virus from invading the body.

The text post included recommendations such as drinking warm water, avoiding crowded places, wearing masks, and loading up on vitamin C. It also listed symptoms of the illness, including repeated high fever, prolonged coughing after fever, and respiratory-related issues. The message urged readers to share the information to help others and concluded with a plea to care for human life.

The photograph of the printed email had similar content, stating that the upper respiratory infection affecting China was serious and caused by a potent virus resistant to antibiotics. It reiterated the importance of keeping the throat moist and provided guidelines for drinking warm water based on age. The email also advised avoiding crowded places, wearing masks, and consuming vitamin C. It listed the same symptoms and emphasized the contagious nature of the illness.

According to the article, the viral social media post was authentic and accurate, representing a legitimate "health bulletin" about the new coronavirus outbreak from an official public health authority. However, the specific source of the alert and the Ministry of Health mentioned in the message were not identified.

In summary, the article confirms that the viral social media post in January 2020 was a genuine health bulletin about the new coronavirus outbreak. The post emphasized the importance of keeping the throat moist, provided prevention methods, and listed symptoms of the illness. It urged readers to share the information and was considered accurate by the article.
Claim: A viral social media post in January 2020 represented an authentic, accurate "health bulletin" about the new coronavirus outbreak from an official public health authority.
The claim veracity: false

### Explanation:
label: false
explanation: Neither the printed email nor the viral Facebook message were official statements produced by any public health authority. The alert was apt to spread widely online precisely because it did not include any details about its supposed source, aside from mentioning a “Ministry of Health” in an unspecified country or region.
claim: A viral social media post in January 2020 represented an authentic, accurate "health bulletin" about the new coronavirus outbreak from an official public health authority.
generated_result: ‘Emergency Notification From Ministry of Health’
