### Context: State prosecutors are facing challenges in drunken-driving cases due to restrictive new evidence standards. These rules, which were implemented as part of legal reform legislation in 2011, make it more difficult to admit police testimony and field sobriety tests into court. The legislation was primarily aimed at blocking unreliable expert testimony and junk science in negligence lawsuits against businesses, but it applies to all civil and criminal actions, including charges of operating while intoxicated (OWI).

The Democratic Party of Wisconsin claimed that the legislation made it easier for drunk drivers who kill to evade punishment. They cited three pieces of evidence to support their claim: opposition from Mothers Against Drunk Drivers (MADD), limits on punitive damages in civil cases, and changes that make it harder for people to testify as experts. However, the claim regarding punitive damages is inaccurate as drunk-driving crash victims are exempt from these limits. MADD initially opposed the legislation but dropped its opposition after the punitive damage exemption was added. They are now seeking a partial legislative fix in response to the new evidence rules.

Prosecutors argue that the new evidence rules put additional pressure on them. The changes have been significant but generally welcomed in concept, as the old standards allowed in too much evidence. The new standards are already used in federal courts and by more than 30 states. While there have been challenges to OWI evidence under the new law, there have been no reported cases of OWI homicide trials being affected by the new evidence standards.

Both prosecutors and defense lawyers in states that already have similar evidence standards have found them to be fairly neutral. Prosecutors have to work harder to defend the reliability of tests and witnesses, while defense attorneys have to introduce better and more reliable evidence. The new standards prevent the defense from using bogus or questionable experts.

Looking ahead, arresting officers and sobriety tests are being challenged under the new system. Judges now act as gatekeepers for reliable and relevant scientific testimony, whereas in the past, juries heard almost everything. Some judges have concerns about certain tests, such as the Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus (HGN) test, which is not allowed as evidence in some states.

Overall, the claim that the legislation makes it easier for drunk drivers who kill to evade punishment has some element of truth. Some defendants have found an easier road due to challenges to scientific evidence. However, it is misleading to suggest that the intent of the legislation was to favor homicidal drunk drivers. Both defense and prosecution are subject to the new evidence standards, and even defense-side experts do not believe it makes it easier for drunk drivers.
Claim: A bill supported by Gov. Scott Walker makes it "so that drunk drivers who kill have an easier time of it.
The claim veracity: false

### Explanation:
label: false
explanation: Wisconsin Democratic Party says Walker supported a law that makes it easier for drunken drivers to escape punishment
claim: A bill supported by Gov. Scott Walker makes it "so that drunk drivers who kill have an easier time of it.
generated_result: Wisconsin Democratic Party says legislation backed by Gov. Scott Walker makes it ""so that drunk drivers who kill have an easier time of it."" There’s some element of truth to this, as some defendants have found an easier road due to challenges to scientific evidence. But it’s misleading to suggest that the intent of the legislation was to favor homicidal drunk drivers. Both defense and prosecution are subject to the new evidence standards, and even defense-side experts don’t think it makes it easier for drunk drivers.

### Context: Greek Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis has suggested that the European Union (EU) should purchase patent rights for vaccines and coronavirus tests in order to ensure a rapid and fair distribution of these medical resources. Mitsotakis emphasized the urgency of finding a solution for the distribution of vaccines once they become available. He stated that at least 20 vaccines against COVID-19 are currently under development, many of which are being subsidized by individual governments or charities.

Mitsotakis argued that purchasing patent rights would provide global pharmaceutical companies with incentives for further research and development, while also ensuring that European taxpayers' money is spent sensibly. The suggestion to buy patent rights was initially proposed by Elias Mossialos, a professor of health policy at the London School of Economics, who has been appointed as Greece's representative in international talks on tackling the coronavirus.

Mossialos explained that the cost for patent rights could be distributed among EU countries, and this approach would only be used in extreme cases such as a pandemic. He reassured that it would not negatively impact the sustainability of the medical technology industry. By securing patent rights at an EU level, the production of tests and vaccines could be expanded to multiple locations, enabling wider distribution.

Europe has become the epicenter of the COVID-19 pandemic, with over 130,000 cases reported. Italy and Spain have been particularly hard-hit by the virus. The proposal to purchase patent rights for vaccines and tests aims to address the urgent need for a rapid and fair distribution of these resources once they are proven effective.

In summary, Greek Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis has suggested that the EU should buy patent rights for vaccines and coronavirus tests to ensure their rapid and fair distribution. This proposal, initially put forward by health policy professor Elias Mossialos, aims to incentivize further research and development while utilizing European taxpayers' money effectively. By securing patent rights at an EU level, the production and distribution of these medical resources can be expanded to multiple locations.
Claim: Greece suggests EU buy patent rights for vaccines and coronavirus tests: FAZ.
The claim veracity: true

### Explanation:
label: true
explanation: Greece has suggested EU member states jointly buy patent rights for vaccines against COVID-19 and rapid tests under development  to help ensure that if they are effective they are quickly distributed to those in need across the bloc.
claim: Greece suggests EU buy patent rights for vaccines and coronavirus tests: FAZ.
generated_result: Greece has proposed that the European Union buy up patent rights for coronavirus tests and vaccines to ensure a rapid and fair distribution of the medical resources, the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung reported, citing a Greek government official.

### Context: The article titled "Drugs may make stents deadly, study says" discusses a new study that suggests an increased risk of fatal blood clots associated with the use of drug-coated stents. The article mentions that the actual magnitude of this risk ranges from 0.6% to 2.6% of patients, but fails to quantify the harms associated with the use of plain metal stents. It also does not provide information about the difference in risk of re-stenosis and thrombosis between these two types of stents.

The article states that patients with drug-coated stents have 30-40% less collateral blood-vessel function compared to those with bare-metal stents. However, it does not explain the absolute difference in collateral blood vessel function or how much is needed for optimum protection. The article also does not fully describe the development of collateral circulation and how less collateral circulation increases the risk to the heart muscle when a clot blocks a portion of the blood supply.

The article lacks information about when the use of a stent is indicated or not, which gives it a disease mongering quality. It quotes one of the authors of the study and an investigator in the field, but does not provide adequate information about treatment options for individuals with partial blockage of coronary arteries. It also fails to mention the role of medical therapy either without stenting or after stent placement.

Although the article mentions the importance of selecting the correct stent for each patient, it does not provide guidance on how to discuss this with doctors. It states that 80% of Americans who are treated with a stent receive a drug-coated stent, but does not mention the indications for stent placement.

Overall, the article reports on the observations from a new study but lacks important information and fails to quantify the benefits and harms associated with different types of stents.

The study found that people with the drug-coated stents had less formation of these vessels. The implication of this was not clearly presented in the story, but with fewer vessels formed, if vessels become blocked, there is less capacity to provide the heart muscle with blood. So there is increased risk of heart muscle damage and death. The story neglected to present the complete array of treatment options for the management of coronary artery disease and did not provide the reader with information on the guideline criteria for the use of stents. This information is necessary for the reader to understand the interventions available for coronary artery disease and to help them with treatment decisions they may face.

### Context: The claim that Nike donated three times more to Republicans than Democrats during the 2018 federal election cycle is accurate, but it requires clarification. The donations were not made by the company itself, but rather by its political action committee (PAC) and individuals listed as employees of Nike. The Center for Responsive Politics, which reported on the donations, explained that they categorize campaign contributions based on the individuals associated with the institution rather than the organization itself. They believe there is a correlation between individuals' contributions and their employers' political interests. 

In the case of Nike, their PAC and employees contributed a total of $547,107 in campaign donations during the 2017-18 election cycle. Of that total, 78 percent ($424,600) went to Republicans and 22 percent ($122,449) went to Democrats. However, it is important to note that the inclusion of contributions by Phil Knight, the billionaire co-founder of Nike and a prolific Republican donor, significantly skewed the partisan breakdown. Knight, who is no longer an employee of Nike, exclusively contributed to Republican campaign committees and candidates. His donations, along with those of his wife, made up almost half of the total donations from Nike employees and the Nike PAC. 

When looking specifically at Nike's PAC, their contributions were much more evenly split between the two main parties. As of September 2018, the Nike Inc. Federal PAC had donated $79,500 to Democratic candidates and $64,000 to Republican candidates. However, when considering donations made by Nike's PAC to other political action committees and campaign committees, the ratio flips, with Nike's PAC donating $104,000 to Republican PACs and candidates and $96,500 to Democratic PACs and candidates. 

In conclusion, while it is true that donors associated with Nike contributed more to Republican candidates than Democrats during the 2018 federal election cycle, it is important to clarify that these donations were made by individuals and the company's PAC, not the company itself. The inclusion of donations by Phil Knight, who is no longer an employee of Nike, significantly skewed the partisan breakdown. Additionally, when looking solely at Nike's PAC, their contributions were fairly evenly split between the two parties.
Claim: Nike donated three times more to Republicans than Democrats during the 2018 federal election cycle, up to August 2018.
The claim veracity: mixture

### Explanation:
label: mixture
explanation: What's true: Individuals who listed their employer as Nike did contribute vastly more to Republicans than to Democrats during the 2018 federal election cycle. What's false: Those contributions were not made by Nike itself as a company and were dominated by donations from Nike's billionaire co-founder Phil Knight, who is no longer actually an employee. Nike's political action committee donated fairly evenly to both Democratic and Republican candidates during the same period.
claim: Nike donated three times more to Republicans than Democrats during the 2018 federal election cycle, up to August 2018.
generated_result: What's true: Donors associated with Nike, including its PAC and employees, contributed $547,107 to federal candidates during the 2017-18 election cycle, with 78 percent of that money going to Republicans. What's false: Nike's PAC and employees did not donate three times more than Nike itself did.

### Context: The article discusses a new portable scanner for breast cancer and raises questions about its cost implications and effectiveness compared to mammography. The article points out that without knowing the sensitivity and specificity of the scanner, it is difficult to determine its role in breast cancer screening. Poor sensitivity could lead to missed cancers, while poor specificity could result in unnecessary biopsies and treatments. The article also questions whether the scanner will be covered by insurance and highlights the need for clinical trials to determine its effectiveness. The article criticizes the lack of discussion about potential downsides and the absence of clinical evidence supporting the scanner. It suggests that the scanner may still be in the prototype stage and emphasizes the importance of evaluating its performance in human beings. The article mentions prior research with RF and microwave technologies in detecting breast cancer and raises the question of whether the new scanner improves survival. It also highlights the challenge of distinguishing between cancer and "pre-cancer" and the need to assess if the scanner can help people live longer. The article concludes by mentioning statistics about mammography and breast cancer in younger women, but questions the source of these statistics.
Claim: New Portable Scanner for Breast Cancer
The claim veracity: false

### Explanation:
label: false
explanation: Nowhere do we hear how far along the research is. The main section doesn’t even allude to evidence, other than to state that more research is to be done, which is true about most everything in medicine except limes for scurvy. As far as a reader can tell, the “new portable scanner” may have yet to leave a laboratory setting. All we know is that it’s been submitted to, and is a finalist for, an engineering & technology award. It’s not the same as clinical research. The article is quick to point out mammography’s low detection rates (sensitivity, perhaps?) in younger women, identifying the problem to be solved, but it never tells us the detection rates for the new tool. The data very well may be unknown. Which means detection rates could be worse! But from the structure of this article, focusing on technology but not evidence, a reader could only conclude the new kid on the block is superior. If we’re lucky, the new kid will make the world a better place. But filing a patent for a device is not the same level of proof as clinical research. People would be shocked to learn how many promising ideas from labs and napkins never survive clinical trials, how many prove to be worse for mankind than what we already do. Science is hard and complex. Last year’s uproar over the new mammography guidelines highlighted that there are important subtleties about screening for cancer, and that clear, balanced communication is crucial. It may sound like we ask a lot of journalists. But really, asking one more question would’ve turned this story around: How far along is this idea? The answer leads us to look beyond the novelty, beyond the theoretical benefits, beyond the entangled claims of the institution and inventor who stand to benefit, and see, simply, whether this idea is better or worse or needs 4 more years in the oven before we can even ask. Mammography isn’t perfect, and an improved screening technique for breast cancer could reduce pain, suffering, and death for many women. But that need doesn’t give journalists a license to hype.

### Context: The article discusses the claim that flashing your car's high beams at a traffic signal will cause it to change from red to green more quickly. It explains that many motorists have tried this and believe it works because they have seen the light change after flashing their high beams. However, the article argues that this belief is a result of the post hoc, ergo propter hoc fallacy, where people assume that because two events occur together, one must have caused the other.

The article explains that traffic signals are equipped with sensors that respond to the flashing of strobe lights on emergency vehicles. These sensors are part of traffic pre-emption systems that allow emergency vehicles to pass through intersections more quickly and safely by providing them with a steady stream of green lights. The adventurous motorist tries to trick these sensors by rapidly flashing their high beams, assuming that it will cause the light to change. However, the article points out that in many cases, the perceived results are simply coincidences, as the light was already about to change from red to green.

The article also mentions that advance sensors are placed in the road ahead of controlled intersections. These sensors detect the passage of a vehicle and place a "call" to the next traffic signal. If no vehicles are waiting at the next cross street, the signal changes from red to green to allow the oncoming car to flow through smoothly. The distance at which drivers start flashing their high beams to influence upcoming signals is often the same distance where advance sensors are placed. This can create the illusion that flashing the high beams causes the lights to change, when in reality, it is the advance sensors detecting the approaching vehicle.

Furthermore, the article highlights that not all intersections are equipped with strobe-detecting sensors, so flashing the high beams at traffic signals that don't have these sensors will have no effect. Even when drivers encounter strobe-enabled signals, the sensors are set to detect a rapid rate of flashing that a human operating a manual headlight switch cannot imitate. Some traffic pre-emption systems now require a specific pattern of flashing to activate.

In conclusion, the article debunks the claim that flashing your car's high beams at a traffic signal will cause it to change from red to green more quickly. It explains that the perceived results are often coincidences, and the belief is based on a fallacy. Additionally, not all intersections have the necessary sensors, and the flashing pattern required is not achievable manually.
Claim: Flashing your car's high beams at a traffic signal will cause it to change from red to green more quickly.
The claim veracity: false

### Explanation:
label: false
explanation: Naturally, a market has developed for transmitters that can effectively trigger traffic pre-emption systems, but the sale of such devices to non-authorized buyers has now been outlawed in most jurisdictions.
claim: Flashing your car's high beams at a traffic signal will cause it to change from red to green more quickly.
generated_result: Flashing your car's high beams at a traffic signal will cause it to change from red to green more quickly.

### Context: A study conducted by researchers at Case Western Reserve University suggests that treating gum disease may reduce symptoms of prostate inflammation. The study found that men who received treatment for gum disease experienced improved symptoms of prostatitis, as well as a reduction in prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels. However, the article points out that the reductions in PSA levels were not statistically significant and that in participants with low levels of inflammation, the mean PSA level actually increased. The article also notes that the study had limitations, including a small sample size and the lack of a control group.

The release of the study suggests that treating periodontal disease could be a necessary approach to reducing prostate inflammation and possibly prostate cancer. However, the article argues that the release should have included information about the social and financial costs of untreated gum disease and prostatitis, as well as the costs of providing dental care to a substantial percentage of the population. It also mentions that dental care is expensive in the United States and insurance coverage is often limited.

The article criticizes the release for not providing quantitative data from the study and for making misleading claims about the reduction in PSA levels. It also suggests that the release should have mentioned the potential harm from untreated gum or prostate disease, as well as the risks and limitations of repeated PSA screening and biopsies. However, it acknowledges that the release does point out the risk to heart patients and pregnant women of untreated periodontal disease.

The article notes that the study does not provide information about how gingivitis was treated, which could have affected the results. It also criticizes the study's title for not reflecting the uncertainty of its findings. However, it concludes that the release does a good job of noting that this is not the first time a link has been suggested between gum and prostate disease.

Overall, the article suggests that while the study provides some evidence for a relationship between gum and prostate disease, the release of the study miscommunicates the findings and fails to provide important context and limitations.
Claim: Treating gum disease reduces prostate symptoms, CWRU researchers find
The claim veracity: mixture

### Explanation:
label: mixture
explanation: This news release from Case Western Reserve University sets out to describe a relatively small study designed to further previous evidence for an observed link between gum disease and prostatitis (inflammation of the prostate). The study focuses on the likely common denominator of a body-wide biological process that releases inflammatory cytokines into blood and tissue, along with other possibilities; and on the clear possibility that non-surgical dental treatment will help. The study report in the journal Dentistry goes to some lengths to caution readers about the very shaky nature of this evidence and the fact that the study was not designed to establish a cause-and-effect relationship between periodontitis (the fancy name for inflammatory gum disease) and high PSA levels in the blood of men with prostatitis symptoms. The study authors also lay out several caveats and limitations of their study, including the small number of participants and lack of a control group. Alas, the release fails to exercise that same wise caution. It misleadingly refers to PSA reductions that were not statistically significant, and states flatly that “Treating gum disease reduced symptoms of prostate inflammation.” This overstates the value of the evidence presented in the study. Both periodontal disease and prostate disease (inflammation, tissue and tooth loss, and cancer) are widespread and have serious health consequences. Indeed, as the release and study point out, the suspected inflammatory process involved in both has also been linked to some forms of heart disease and autoimmune forms of arthritis. As a result, promoting dental care for gum disease as a means of reducing PSA levels and prostatitis (potential precursor signs of prostate cancer) poses a tantalizing means of controlling real health problems. Promoting evidence that supports the value of dental therapy in this context, however, should be accompanied by caution about the well-known debates over the meaning of high or low  PSA levels (especially in younger men and with only a single PSA test); and caution as well about the limitations of self-reported symptoms of prostatitis in a study with no control group. The authors of the study provide important context on these issues; we wish the news release had followed that lead.
claim: Treating gum disease reduces prostate symptoms, CWRU researchers find

The release also should have mentioned the risks and limitations of repeated PSA screening and biopsies. The release would have been stronger if it had included quantitative data from the study and mentioned the social and financial costs of untreated gum disease and prostatitis. ### Context: A Facebook post claiming that the Trump administration fired 54 scientists and cut off 77 grants at Anthony Fauci's National Institutes of Health (NIH) for not disclosing ties to Communist China is misleading. While it is true that 54 scientists were either fired or resigned as a result of an NIH investigation into scientists failing to disclose financial ties to other countries, the claim falsely links Fauci to the investigation. Fauci is the director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, which is part of NIH, but he is not directly involved in the investigation. The director of NIH is Francis Collins.

The NIH, which is the largest public funder of biomedical research, expressed concerns in 2018 about researchers at NIH-funded institutions failing to disclose contributions from foreign organizations, including foreign governments. The agency pledged to investigate any failures to report substantial contributions. In a recent report, NIH stated that 54 scientists have resigned or been fired, and 77 scientists have been removed from the NIH system, making them ineligible for NIH grants. The hidden funding in 93% of the cases came from Chinese institutions.

The article also mentions a prominent case involving Charles Lieber, the former chair of Harvard University's Chemistry and Chemical Biology Department. Lieber was indicted for making false statements regarding his participation in China's Thousand Talents Program. His research at the Lieber Research Group had received over $15 million in grants from NIH and the Defense Department. It is alleged that Lieber became a "strategic scientist" at Wuhan University of Technology in China and received significant financial support from the university.

In summary, the claim that the Trump administration fired 54 scientists and cut off 77 grants at Fauci's NIH for not disclosing ties to Communist China is misleading. While the firings and removals from the NIH system did occur, the claim falsely links Fauci to the investigation. Additionally, the grants were not cut off, but rather the scientists became ineligible for NIH grants. The investigation primarily focused on undisclosed financial ties to foreign countries, with a significant number of cases involving China.
Claim: “Trump administration just FIRED 54 scientists & cut off 77 grants at Fauci's NIH for not disclosing their ties to Communist China!”
The claim veracity: mixture

### Explanation:
label: mixture
explanation: 54 scientists were fired or resigned as part of a probe by the National Institutes of Health into scientists allegedly failing to disclose financial ties to foreign countries, primarily China. 77 scientists have been removed from the NIH system, meaning they are no longer eligible for NIH grants. Grants weren’t “cut off.”   All the scientists worked at NIH-funded institutions, such as universities. They were not employed as NIH scientists. Fauci leads the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, not the NIH.
claim: “Trump administration just FIRED 54 scientists & cut off 77 grants at Fauci's NIH for not disclosing their ties to Communist China!”
generated_result: Did Trump Fire 54 Scientists, Cut Off 77 Grants at Fauci’s NIH?

### Context: The article discusses a claim that has been circulating on Facebook regarding the number 322 and its connection to COVID-19. The claim suggests that there is something nefarious going on and that COVID-19 cases are being "synchronized" worldwide. The article debunks this claim by explaining that the number 322 can be found in various news headlines related to COVID-19, but this does not indicate any conspiracy. The article points out that during a global pandemic, there is an unprecedented amount of media coverage focused on COVID-19, and counting statistics are readily available through online searches. With thousands of media outlets reporting on COVID-19 cases and deaths, it is not surprising that the number 322 or any other number in the low three-digit range can be found in headlines. The article also mentions that there are numerous local and regional units of government reporting COVID-19 data, which further increases the likelihood of finding tallies that add up to 322. To support their argument, the article conducted a Google News search using different numbers in the low three-digit range along with the term "COVID." The search results showed that there are media reports citing various numbers in that range, indicating that the claim of synchronization is baseless. The article concludes by stating that the claim linking the number 322 to COVID-19 is ridiculous, given the volume of media reports and the number of local and regional units of government involved. The article rates the claim as false.
Claim: Facebook post Says news stories referencing 322 and COVID-19 are proof cases are being “synchronized”
The claim veracity: false

### Explanation:
label: false
explanation: The volume of media coverage and the number of local and regional government units around the world provide ample opportunities for cases or deaths to sum to any number. You can find this “connection” for any low three-digit number. A Google News search shows 322 isn’t even a particularly common tally.
claim: Facebook post Says news stories referencing 322 and COVID-19 are proof cases are being “synchronized”
generated_result: A Facebook post claims news stories referencing 322 and COVID-19 are proof cases are being “synchronized.” That’s ridiculous, given the volume of media reports and the number of local and regional units of government involved.

### Context: The article discusses the efforts of consumer goods companies, such as Procter & Gamble (P&G), The Body Shop, and Unilever, to promote the use of refillable containers for their products as a way to reduce plastic waste. P&G has started offering refill pouches for some of its Olay face-cream jars and plans to expand sales of these pouches in Europe next year. The Body Shop plans to introduce "refill stations" in its stores globally, allowing customers to buy reusable metal containers to fill with shower gels or creams. Unilever has announced the launch of "refill sticks" for its Dove line of personal care products on Loopstore.com, a website that offers durable packaging with refills delivered to consumers' doors.

However, the article highlights that the results for refillable products have been mixed so far. Many shoppers are resistant to change and prefer the convenience of single-use products. Refills are generally priced 20% to 30% less than the containers they replenish, but consumers have not embraced them. SC Johnson, the maker of Windex and Pledge, has experienced flat sales for refills and concentrates over the past decade. Unilever's previous attempts to introduce refillable options, such as 20-liter tanks in Walmart's Asda supermarkets, faced issues with leaky machines, safety concerns, and high maintenance costs.

Despite these challenges, companies are still expanding their refill offerings to address plastic waste concerns. SC Johnson is testing refill stations for cleaning products with UK retailer Waitrose and is considering expanding the project. The Body Shop responded to customer demands and is bringing back refill counters in its stores. P&G acknowledges that selling refills for beauty products like shampoo and creams is more complicated due to the importance of packaging in creating customer loyalty.

Overall, while there is consumer demand for refillable products, availability and convenience remain key factors in their adoption. Companies are investing in refill options to address sustainability concerns, but they face challenges in changing consumer behavior and preferences.

### Context: Their study, published online in the American Journal of Public Health, is the first to look at suicide trends by age and business cycles, and it found that working Americans — people aged 25 to 64 — are significantly more prone to suicide in tough economic times. Researchers looked at the impact of business cycles on U.S. suicide rates from 1928 through 2007. They found a general correlation among suicide rates and major shifts in the U.S. economy. For example, suicides famously spiked during the Great Depression, surging to a record high of 22 suicides per 100,000 people in 1932, up from 18 per 100,000 in 1928. But other slowdowns also saw an increase in suicides, including the end of the New Deal (1937-1938), the Oil Crisis (1973-1975), and the Double-Dip Recession (1980-1982.) And suicide rates tended to fall during periods of plenty, such as during World War Two and the decade-long expansion from 1991 to 2001, in which the economy flourished and there were low rates of unemployment. “Knowing suicides increased during economic recessions and fell during expansions underscores the need for additional suicide prevention measures when the economy weakens,” James Mercy, acting director of CDC’s Injury Center’s Division of Violence Prevention, said in a statement. “It is an important finding for policy makers and those working to prevent suicide.”
Claim: Suicides rise and fall with economy: CDC report.
The claim veracity: true

### Explanation:
label: true
explanation: Suicides in the United States ebb and flow with the economy, rising in bad times and falling in good, researchers at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Thursday.
claim: Suicides rise and fall with economy: CDC report.
generated_result: The Great Depression, the 1970s Oil Crisis and the Double-Dip Recession of the early 1980s all had one thing in common: a spike in suicides.

### Context: Former Vice President Dick Cheney claimed that on the issue of Syria, many allies were ready to take military action but President Obama backed off at the last minute. However, this claim is not entirely accurate. While some countries, such as France, Turkey, and Saudi Arabia, initially expressed support for military intervention, their support waned over time. The United Kingdom, Germany, and Italy were among the key allies that did not support military action. In fact, the British parliament rejected a motion to back the use of force, which was a significant blow to Prime Minister David Cameron. The Arab League and the United Nations also did not endorse military action. Ultimately, President Obama decided not to pursue military action in Syria because the Syrian government agreed to weapons inspections. Therefore, Cheney's claim that "a lot of the allies signed on" is not supported by the facts.

The claim veracity: false

label: false

We counted France, Turkey and Saudi Arabia as countries that were supportive. And France’s support seemed to wane as time went on. Among the "no" crowd were key allies like the United Kingdom, Germany and Italy. In fact, the United Kingdom’s parliament offered an embarrassing rebuke to Cameron when it blocked British participation. The Arab League did not endorse the military action, nor did the United Nations. Obama has said he declined to pursue military action because Syria agreed to weapons inspections. There’s no dispute that for whatever reason, military action was not pursued in Syria. But Cheney was re-writing history when he said "a lot of the allies signed on."

### Context: A study has shown that therapy for sleep apnea can improve the quality of life for patients. However, the news release about the study failed to mention the costs of CPAP home machines, which can be expensive and may pose a financial obstacle for many people, especially those from lower socio-economic backgrounds. The release also did not provide any specific numbers or indicators to demonstrate how much the intervention helped. Common side effects of CPAP therapy, such as congestion and stomach bloating, were not mentioned in the release. The study itself had limitations, including being a retrospective study with no control arm, which should have been included in the release. The first author of the study had ties to industry companies that profit from the sale and upkeep of CPAP machines, which is a financial conflict of interest that should have been disclosed. The release also did not mention alternative treatments for sleep apnea, such as dental appliances, surgery, and nerve stimulation. The availability of CPAP machines was not discussed, despite being easy to find, and low-cost options were not mentioned. The main issue with the news release is that it presents the effectiveness of CPAP therapy as news, despite the fact that it has been extensively studied since the 1970s. The study authors attempted to establish the novelty of their research by highlighting the large sample size and the use of two different questionnaires, but it is unclear if this is enough to warrant a news release on a well-established treatment. The news release did not use unjustifiable or sensational language.
Claim: Study shows therapy improves quality of life in people who have sleep apnea.
The claim veracity: false

### Explanation:
label: false
explanation: This news release from the American Academy of Sleep Medicine describes a large retrospective study that shows that positive airway pressure (PAP) therapy improves quality of life in patients with obstructive sleep apnea. PAP therapy is often given via CPAP (continuous positive airway pressure) machines, and has been a standard treatment for sleep apnea for several decades. The release does a good job describing the study itself, and how the authors broke down patients into subgroups that compared age and socio-economic status. But the release also left much to be desired: it didn’t describe the limitations of retrospective studies or adequately discuss the harms or costs of these machines, which can be prohibitively expensive for some patients. Most importantly, the news release did not do a good job of establishing the novelty of this study. While there was a large sample size and various measures of quality of life, it is still unclear how this study is new since the benefits of CPAP are already well known. Obstructive sleep apnea is a common condition in the United States (and the world). It affects about 20 million adult Americans each year, and significantly decreases quality of life due to poor sleep. Sufferers of sleep apnea report daytime symptoms as well, which can include drowsiness, moodiness, headaches, and lack of energy. However sleep apnea is also a well-studied condition, and it is already known that there are several interventions, including use of a CPAP machine, that can help improve symptoms and quality of life. It would be more newsworthy if the researchers had learned something different or new about CPAP treatment or sleep apnea, instead of re-establishing what has already been known for years. The most interesting thing from this news release was that those in lower socio-economic subgroups seemed to benefit less from PAP therapy–perhaps this is a region worth further study.
claim: Study shows therapy improves quality of life in people who have sleep apnea.

The release also doesn’t mention any potential harms of CPAP therapy, which can be significant. The release also doesn’t mention any alternative treatments for sleep apnea, such as dental appliances, surgery, and nerve stimulation. The release also doesn’t mention the study’s limitations, which are significant. The study is a retrospective study with no control arm, which should have been included in the release. The release also doesn’t mention the first author’s ties to industry companies that profit from the sale and upkeep of CPAP machines, which is a financial conflict of interest. The release also doesn’t mention any numbers or indicators to demonstrate how much the intervention helped. Common side effects of CPAP therapy, such as congestion and stomach bloating, are also not mentioned. The study authors attempted to establish the novelty of their research by highlighting the large sample size and the use of two different questionnaires, but it is unclear if this is enough to warrant a news release on a well-established treatment.

### Context: A study conducted in Canada found that low-income women who received prenatal care from midwives had lower odds of birth complications compared to those who received care from general practitioners or obstetricians. The study looked at three specific pregnancy outcomes: babies who were small for gestational age, had a low birth weight, or were delivered pre-term. The study included 57,872 women who had received medical insurance premium assistance. The news release stated that midwifery care is generally less costly than care provided by specialists in obstetrics and gynecology and general practitioners.

However, the news release did not provide absolute numbers to give readers an idea of the size of the difference in outcomes. It also did not mention the study's findings on the reduction in odds of early labor or low birth weight babies for women who used midwives. The study did not address maternal health outcomes and did not provide information on potential harms of midwifery care.

The study was based on observational data, which means that cause-and-effect conclusions cannot be drawn. The authors noted that a causal relationship between midwife care and better outcomes would need to be established through repeated observational studies with representative samples over time. However, a researcher quoted in the news release made a cause-and-effect conclusion, stating that the findings show that women who are more vulnerable benefit from the care of a midwife.

The news release did not engage in disease-mongering and mentioned that midwifery is not available in all parts of the country. It also highlighted the importance of expanding midwifery to make it available for all women, especially those who are more vulnerable and may not be aware of the services available to them.

The news release did not disclose how the study was funded, but it mentioned that the lead author had been providing consulting services to the Midwives Association of BC. Overall, the news release presented midwifery as a safe option for prenatal care, particularly for low-income women, without using unjustifiable language.
Claim: Midwifery linked to lower odds of birth complications for low-income women
The claim veracity: mixture

### Explanation:
label: mixture
explanation: This news release touted an observational study that found low-income women in British Columbia who used midwives for prenatal care experienced fewer complications than those who used general practitioners or obstetricians. The study was published in the British Medical Journal Open. Commendably, the release used mostly cautious language, stating the study adds “new evidence in support of midwives as a safe option.” However, it did not quantify adequately the differences in the outcomes or explain the limitations of observational data. Midwifery can fill an important need for wider access to care for pregnant women. Advocates for midwives say they reduce unnecessary care, cost less, and lead to great patient satisfaction. Still, news releases should stress the need for ongoing research to assess how the use of midwives affects pregnancy outcomes. The research report describes the study’s context well, noting that at this stage in the evolution of midwifery care in Canada, a randomized trial could not be supported based on the limited evidence that midwifery care is at least as good as traditional care. Studies such as this one, while not providing a definitive answer, add to our knowledge of the safety of midwifery care and pave the way for further studies that establish its benefits and risks.
claim: Midwifery linked to lower odds of birth complications for low-income women
generated_result: This news release from the University of British Columbia describes a study that compared the outcomes of low-income women who received prenatal care from midwives to those who received care from general practitioners or obstetricians. The news release did a good job of describing the study and the benefits of midwifery care. However, it did not provide absolute numbers to give readers an idea of the size of the difference in outcomes. It also did not mention the study’s findings on the reduction in odds of early labor or low birth weight babies for women who used midwives. The news release also used cause-and-effect language when the study was observational and could not establish a causal relationship between midwife care and better outcomes. The news release did a good job of describing the study and the benefits of midwifery care. However, it did not provide absolute numbers to give readers an idea of the size of the difference in outcomes. It also did not mention the study’s findings on the reduction in odds of early labor or low birth weight babies for women who used midwives. The news release also used cause-and-effect language when the study was observational and could not establish a causal relationship between midwife care and better outcomes.

### Context: The article discusses a study on a new experimental drug called briakinumab for the treatment of psoriasis. The study found that briakinumab was more effective than the older treatment, methotrexate, in reducing the symptoms of psoriasis. The article provides a detailed explanation of the study's findings, including the benefits of briakinumab and the potential risks associated with its use.

The article also mentions the high costs of biologic drugs, such as briakinumab, which can range from $1,500 to $2,000 per month. It criticizes the lack of discussion on the costs of these drugs in the article, stating that any discussion about a new drug should include some comment about its costs.

The article praises the article for providing a more complete explanation of the serious infections and two cancer cases seen in the briakinumab group. It also mentions that a previous trial of the drug showed some unexplained major adverse cardiac events. The article compares this to a competing WebMD story, which it believes did not provide as thorough an explanation.

The article concludes with a quote from a spokesperson from the National Psoriasis Foundation, stating that the study shows "dramatic progress" in the treatment of psoriasis. The article appreciates this measured and responsible message, without exaggerating the implications of the study.

However, the article criticizes the lack of disclosure in the article regarding the funding and involvement of Abbott Labs, the manufacturer of briakinumab, in the study. It states that the article did not disclose that the principal investigator of the study had financial ties to Abbott Labs, and that Abbott personnel helped write the manuscript and analyze the data. The article believes that this lack of disclosure is unsatisfactory.

The article also mentions that neither the article nor the competing WebMD story provided a broader context of other approaches to psoriasis, including non-drug therapies. It believes that the experimental nature of briakinumab was made clear in the article, but that the WebMD story did a better job of mentioning a similar drug, Stelara, which was approved by the FDA in 2009.

Overall, the article provides a summary and critique of an article discussing the effectiveness of briakinumab for the treatment of psoriasis. It highlights the benefits and risks of the drug, criticizes the lack of discussion on costs and disclosure of funding, and compares it to a competing WebMD story.
Claim: Experimental Psoriasis Drug Bests Older Treatment
The claim veracity: mixture

### Explanation:
label: mixture
explanation: But neither story disclosed the conflicts of interest of the principal investigator. It’s difficult sometimes for journalists to dig and find conflicts of interest in those making claims about health care interventions. But when the conflicts are disclosed and published for anyone to see, why would a news story fail to include that information in a story? And neither story discussed the costs of biolgic drugs in the treatment of psoriasis. These drugs can cost $1,500-2,000/month. We think that any discussion about a new drug should include some comment about costs. Psoriasis is a chronic skin condition that, in its more aggressive forms, can produce a good deal of discomfort and disfigurement. Treatments to date have improved but a mainstay drug, methotrexate, is limited in its effectiveness and can have some nasty side effects. Biologic drugs such as Stelara, Humira and Enbrel are somewhat more effective but very expensive. So a story about a new drug that appears effective in very early clinical trials is important.
claim: Experimental Psoriasis Drug Bests Older Treatment
generated_result: This was a good summary of a study on a new drug for psoriasis. It did a good job of describing the benefits and harms of the drug. It could have been improved by mentioning the costs of the drug and by making it more clear that the study was funded by the manufacturer of the drug. It also could have been improved by mentioning other approaches to psoriasis, including non-drug therapies. The competing WebMD story did a better job of mentioning a similar drug, Stelara, which was approved by the FDA in 2009.

### Context: The claim that teenage boys widely purchased and used the Jiftip, a urethra-covering adhesive band, in 2017 and 2018 is not supported by evidence. The Jiftip is a product designed to offer men an alternative to condoms during sex. It was registered as a trademark in the United States in 2016 by Sumina Global Limited. The company's marketing director, Momo Sumina, applied for a patent for the device in 2014 and again in 2016. The patent application describes the device as a barrier layer made of flexible material with an adhesive layer that attaches to the glans of the penis to block fluid from exiting the urethra opening. However, as of June 2018, the patent application had not been granted.

The Jiftip website features a shopping cart where users can purchase the adhesive strips. However, there is no evidence beyond the website itself that anyone has actually bought the product. The website now includes disclaimers about the safety of using Jiftip and emphasizes that it is not a condom alternative but a sexual pleasure enhancement device. The product is not available for purchase on popular online platforms like Amazon, eBay, or Google.

Despite the novelty of the product and the attention it received in the media, there is no evidence of widespread usage. There are no Facebook or Twitter posts or photos from the public showing experimentation with the product, and no product reviews from journalists or consumer websites. The article reached out to the makers of Jiftip for sales figures and information on future marketing plans but did not receive a response.

In conclusion, the claim that teenage boys widely purchased and used the Jiftip adhesive band in 2017 and 2018 is not supported by evidence. While the product exists and is available for purchase on the Jiftip website, there is no indication that it has gained significant popularity or that teenagers are specifically opting for it.
Claim: In 2017 and 2018, teenage boys widely purchased and used a urethra-covering adhesive band called the Jiftip.
The claim veracity: mixture

### Explanation:
label: mixture
explanation: What's true: The Jiftip product does exist and appears to be for sale. What's false: There is scant evidence that anyone (including teenagers) is buying the product.
claim: In 2017 and 2018, teenage boys widely purchased and used a urethra-covering adhesive band called the Jiftip.
generated_result: What's true: The Jiftip is a real product that is available for purchase on the company's website. What's false: There is no evidence that the product is widely used, or that teenage boys are buying it.

### Context: The article addresses the claim that the Trump administration under-prepared the United States to deal with the coronavirus outbreak and that his budget cuts had hindered federal health agencies. It is true that Trump's fiscal year 2021 budget proposal includes a funding cut to the CDC, but this budget has not been enacted yet. The proposed funding cuts target the CDC's chronic disease activities, with the aim of focusing on preventing and controlling infectious diseases and emerging public health issues like opioid abuse. The budget also reduces overall funding for global health but allocates an extra $50 million for global health security measures. However, international HIV/AIDS programs are being cut by about $58 million.

It is important to note that this is not the first time the Trump administration has proposed cuts to the CDC budget, but such proposals do not always result in actual funding cuts. Congress has consistently overruled these proposals due to strong bipartisan support for agencies like the CDC and NIH, resulting in increased financing. The initial funding used by the CDC to combat the coronavirus outbreak came from a congressional fund created for health emergencies.

While the article acknowledges the budget cuts proposed by the Trump administration, it also highlights that a bigger concern is the decline of a CDC grant program for state and local public health emergency preparedness. This decline was initiated by a congressional budget measure that predates Trump.

In summary, the claim that President Trump cut funding for the CDC is partially true. While his budget proposal includes funding cuts, it has not been enacted yet, and previous proposals for cuts have been overruled by Congress. The article also emphasizes that the erosion of a CDC grant program for public health emergency preparedness is a more significant concern, and this decline was not solely caused by the Trump administration but also by a congressional budget measure.
Claim: U.S. President Donald Trump cut funding for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).
The claim veracity: mixture

### Explanation:
label: mixture
explanation: What's true: The Trump administration's proposed 2021 budget includes cuts to the CDC's activities related to chronic disease. What's false: Congress hasn't approved the budget, so CDC funding in 2021 remains unclear.
claim: U.S. President Donald Trump cut funding for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).
generated_result: What's true: The Trump administration has proposed cutting the CDC's budget, as it has in previous years. What's false: The CDC has not yet seen any cuts to its budget.

### Context: The article discusses conservative radio host Glenn Beck's claim that every time someone new gets the Ebola virus, it mutates. The article explains that while it is true that the Ebola virus mutates, not every mutation makes the virus more deadly or difficult to treat. Most mutations actually reduce the fitness of the virus and are lost from the population. The article also explains that the Ebola virus largely works through the proteins it produces, and most mutations result in proteins that do not help the virus infect more parts of the body. 

The article cites infectious disease researchers who confirm that the virus does mutate, but they emphasize that not every mutation has a significant impact on the virus. They explain that most mutations do not change the protein sequence, which is what determines how the virus works. The researchers also mention a study that found 40 mutations in the Ebola virus, but only a third of them were non-synonymous mutations that could potentially change the proteins in the virus. Of those non-synonymous mutations, it is unclear whether they actually made the virus more successful or able to spread to new individuals.

The article also mentions that even if mutations occur in a victim's bloodstream, they may not be passed on to others. The researchers found instances where mutations appeared but did not result in transmissions, suggesting that the mutations died off.

Overall, the article concludes that while it is true that the Ebola virus mutates, not every mutation is significant or leads to a more dangerous form of the virus. The claim made by Glenn Beck that every time someone new gets the Ebola virus, it mutates is partially accurate but leaves out important details.
Claim: Every time somebody new gets the Ebola virus, it mutates.
The claim veracity: mixture

### Explanation:
label: mixture
explanation: Beck warned that every time someone new gets the Ebola virus, it mutates. First, mutation and replication go hand in hand and infecting a new person doesn’t change that. But the much larger point is that Beck is painting mutations with a broad brush. Most of them hurt the virus and are automatic dead-ends. Of those that don’t actually hurt it, about two-thirds don’t change how Ebola functions. Of those that change how the virus functions, there’s no data to say whether the functional changes matter. However, the most recent study in West Africa found that many new varieties are not passed on to new victims. Beck’s statement about Ebola mutations is partially accurate but leaves out important details.
claim: Every time somebody new gets the Ebola virus, it mutates.
generated_result: Beck said, ""Every time somebody new gets the Ebola virus, it mutates."" It’s true that the Ebola virus mutates, but not every mutation is significant. Beck’s claim is partially accurate but leaves out important details.

### Context: The article discusses a new cancer treatment called the NanoKnife and raises questions about its effectiveness and lack of scientific evidence. The machine costs around $300,000, but Medicare does not specifically cover its use. Some private insurers, like Arkansas BlueCross BlueShield, also decline to cover it due to the lack of scientific evidence of its effectiveness in improving health outcomes.

The article mentions that the NanoKnife has some reported side effects, such as triggering fast heartbeats and the possibility of puncturing an artery during the operation. However, the company behind the NanoKnife claims that these side effects have been treatable and that they have taken steps to minimize future occurrences.

The story highlights the lack of evidence for the benefits of the NanoKnife due to the limited number of human patients it has been tested on. It questions why the company thinks the results are promising and does not provide a comparison with other traditional surgical approaches for treating cancer.

The article quotes several outside experts, including Riad Salem, chief of interventional oncology at Northwestern Memorial Hospital, Ken Thomson, a radiologist in Australia who studied the devices, and Tim Clark, director of interventional radiology at Penn Presbyterian Medical Center. These experts provide their opinions on the NanoKnife and its claims.

The story also distinguishes between the claims made by the company and the claims made by the clinics and hospitals that have purchased the machines. The CEO of the machine manufacturer states that they are not part of the PR machine and are not happy about it.

The NanoKnife is currently being used in about 13 U.S. hospitals and has been used to treat around 300 cancer patients worldwide. The article mentions that similar devices have been used for other procedures, but the NanoKnife is a relatively new therapy for cancer.

Overall, the article raises concerns about the lack of evidence for the NanoKnife's effectiveness and the limited coverage by Medicare and private insurers. It also highlights the reported side effects and the need for more comparative data with traditional surgical approaches.
Claim: Some Doctors Question New Cancer Treatment
The claim veracity: true

### Explanation:
label: true
explanation: This story shows how "a shortcut the Food and Drug Administration allows for granting regulatory approval to certain medical devices" has allowed the NanoKnife, an experimental treatment with very limited evidence, to be touted as the latest cure for cancer. The story hits nearly all of our marks, although we wish there were more detail in areas such as costs, potential benefits, and the overall evaluation of the evidence. This device is the type one might see advertised on the side of a bus or in the back pages of of a weekly tabloid. Health reporters often ignore these claims to focus on the higher profile blockbuster drugs being sold by major drug companies or some breakthrough discovery in a major scientific journal. The promotion and use of these under-researched devices can have devastating consquences for patients. In addition, one of the major drivers of increasing health care costs is the introduction of new technologies. While additional costs may be justified if there is an improvement in patient outcomes associated with the new technology, newer is not always better. The NanoKnife is the latest in a series of new devices, approved by the FDA, that have yet to demonstrate a substantive improvement in patient outcomes. Hospital promotion of new technologies is now rivaling that of other commercial interests with unsubstantiated claims.
claim: Some Doctors Question New Cancer Treatment

The story also does a good job of describing the lack of evidence for the device’s benefits. The story could have been improved by describing the costs of the device and by describing the alternatives to the device. The story does a good job of describing the device and its potential harms. ### Context: An FDA advisory panel has recommended the approval of Exelon (rivastigmine), a drug developed by Novartis, for the treatment of dementia associated with Parkinson's disease. The panel believes the drug to be safe, but the article does not mention any side effects or harms of rivastigmine. The story does not provide any cost information for the drug, nor does it quantify any benefits or describe what improvements might be expected. The article also does not mention any evidence for the therapeutic claims of rivastigmine for treating Parkinson's disease.

The FDA panel's recommendation for approval is based solely on studies conducted by the manufacturer, which raises concerns about the lack of independent input. While rivastigmine may provide some improvement in dementia symptoms among some people with certain forms of Alzheimer's disease, it is not known whether long-term outcomes, such as nursing home admission, are improved with the drug. It is also unclear whether the drug would have the same effects in a different population, such as those with Parkinson's disease, and if so, whether those effects would be meaningful.

The article does not engage in disease mongering and provides simple descriptions of both Alzheimer's and Parkinson's disease. However, more information about these conditions could have been useful. The story also fails to mention other treatment options, such as memantine.

While the FDA usually follows the advice of the advisory panel, there is no discussion of when the FDA might approve the drug for this indication. The article does mention that Exelon is currently on the market for the treatment of mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease, indicating that the drug is not new but is being considered for a new purpose.

Overall, the article lacks important information about the cost, benefits, and potential side effects of rivastigmine. It also does not provide independent input on the therapeutic claims of the drug or mention other treatment options. The lack of information about the FDA's next steps and potential approval timeline is also a notable omission.
Claim: FDA Panel Backs Novartis Drug For Treating Parkinson’s Dementia
The claim veracity: false

label: false
explanation: The story reports that an FDA advisory panel recommended an existing drug (rivastigmine) be approved for a new use – the treatment of dementia in people with Parkinson’s disease. The story adequately tells readers that the drug is not new, but is being considered for a new purpose. It doesn’t seem to exaggerate the condition (although more info might have been useful). However, several other areas could be improved, including discussion of costs, side effects, benefits, a description of the evidence upon which claims are based, and other treatment options. It would be a concern if this story leaves readers thinking there may be a good treatment option for Parkinson’s dementia that’s about to become available, when this may not be the case. It isn’t clear that this treatment even works in Parkinson’s, and if it does work, that any benefits are meaningful either in the short-run or long-run.

### Context: A recent study has found that a cannabis derivative called cannabidiol (CBD) can significantly reduce seizures in patients with a severe form of epilepsy called Dravet syndrome. The study was a randomized, placebo-controlled trial, which is considered the highest standard of evidence. The results showed that seizure frequency dropped by 39% in the CBD-treated group, with three patients experiencing a complete cessation of seizures. In comparison, the placebo group saw a 13% reduction in seizures. The difference in seizure reduction between the two groups was both statistically significant and clinically consistent.

The study also noted the side effects of CBD use, with 93.4% of patients in the CBD group experiencing side effects compared to 74.6% in the placebo group. The most common side effects in the CBD group were vomiting, fatigue, and fever. Eight participants from the CBD group withdrew from the trial due to side effects, while only one participant from the placebo group withdrew.

The study was funded by GW Pharmaceuticals, the manufacturer of Epidiolex, the CBD drug used in the trial. The trial involved adding Epidiolex to the patients' existing treatment over a 14-week period, indicating that other treatments are available but CBD is an add-on treatment, not an alternative.

It is important to note that Epidiolex has not been approved by the FDA yet, but the FDA considers cannabidiol an investigational product for treating children with epilepsy and has provisions for expanded access that allow its use.

The release of the study results coincides with their publication in the New England Journal of Medicine. The release emphasizes that while CBD shows promise as a treatment option for severe forms of epilepsy, it should not be viewed as a panacea. The lead researcher states that for patients who have not responded to numerous medications, CBD provides hope for another treatment option.

Overall, the study provides evidence that CBD can reduce seizures in patients with Dravet syndrome, but further research is needed to determine the optimal dosage and potential long-term effects.
Claim: Cannabis Derivative Cannabidiol Reduces Seizures in Severe Epilepsy Disorder
The claim veracity: true

### Explanation:
label: true
explanation: This release from the NYU Langone Medical Center describes a randomized placebo controlled clinical trial of children and adolescents with Dravet syndome, an extreme form of epilepsy, who often don’t respond to other drugs. The release provides a very good description of the benefits and the side effects that were reported from the trial. It adds cautions and nuance that are missing from many news releases. But not included were the cost of the new drug (projected to be quite steep) and we think the release could have emphasized more that the children in the trial were already on seizure medications. When the cannabidiol (or a placebo) was added to the maintenance drug it alleviated seizures but also introduced a high degree of side effects. A CNN story on the study, which we also reviewed, had many of the same strengths as the news release (overall depth and detail on benefits), but it similarly skipped cost information. Dravet syndrome is a rare form of epilepsy that generally begins in a child’s first year but is a life-long condition, according to the Epilepsy Foundation. Currently, treatments for this condition are marginal and new therapies addressing its symptoms would be welcome. The trial showed reduced seizures in this difficult-to-treat type of epilepsy compared to patients given a placebo. The lead researcher stressed that the study only tested cannabidiol in patients “with especially severe forms who have not responded to numerous medications”  and that the drug is not a panacea for other forms of epilepsy.
claim: Cannabis Derivative Cannabidiol Reduces Seizures in Severe Epilepsy Disorder
generated_result: This news release describes a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of a drug called cannabidiol (CBD) for the treatment of Dravet syndrome, a rare and severe form of epilepsy. The study was published in the New England Journal of Medicine. The release does a good job of describing the study and its results, and of explaining the potential harms of the drug. It would have been stronger if it had mentioned the cost of the drug, which is not yet available, and if it had been more clear about the fact that the study was funded by the drug’s manufacturer. Dravet syndrome is a rare and severe form of epilepsy that begins in infancy. It is characterized by frequent seizures, developmental delay, and cognitive impairment. The seizures are resistant to treatment with currently available medications. The syndrome is caused by a mutation in a gene that encodes a potassium channel in the brain. The mutation results in the channel being more open than it should be, which can lead to seizures. The drug cannabidiol (CBD) is a derivative of cannabis that is being studied for its potential to treat seizures in patients with Dravet syndrome. The drug is not yet available, but it is being developed by GW Pharmaceuticals under the trade name Epidiolex.

### Context: The article discusses the effectiveness of the experimental drug Tykerb (generic name lapatinib) in the treatment of metastatic HER-2 positive breast cancer. The drug manufacturer, GlaxoSmithKline, claims that Tykerb has shown promising results in a trial of metastatic breast cancer patients. The addition of lapatinib to chemotherapy resulted in cancers remaining stable for nearly twice as long compared to chemotherapy alone (8.5 months vs. 4.5 months). There were also fewer incidents of cancer spreading to the brain in patients who took lapatinib and chemotherapy compared to chemotherapy alone (4 vs. 11 cases). The article notes that survival data or data on quality of life would be helpful to support these claims.

The article mentions that lapatinib has shown less serious cardiac side effects compared to Herceptin, another treatment for HER-2 positive breast cancer. However, the comparison with Herceptin is not fair as there is not enough information on the length of time patients took lapatinib and Herceptin to make a statistically significant comparison. The article also highlights that long-term cardiac problems are less of an issue for metastatic patients, but it could be a concern for early-stage breast cancer patients, for whom lapatinib is being tested as an alternative to Herceptin.

The article acknowledges that the trial for lapatinib was conducted in only 392 patients and was not a head-to-head comparison with Herceptin. It also mentions that the sources cited in the article are associated with GlaxoSmithKline, the sponsor of the study. The article suggests that additional perspectives from independent oncology researchers would be beneficial.

The article mentions that lapatinib is still being tested in clinical trials and is not yet available for sale. GlaxoSmithKline plans to submit the drug for regulatory approval in the US and Europe by the end of the year. The article notes that the company has high hopes for Tykerb.

Overall, the article provides information on the effectiveness of lapatinib in metastatic breast cancer patients but highlights the need for more data on survival and quality of life. It also raises concerns about the comparison with Herceptin and the potential cardiac side effects of lapatinib. The article suggests that additional perspectives from independent researchers would provide a more balanced view.
Claim: Glaxo Touts Experimental Tykerb As Effective Breast-Cancer Treament
The claim veracity: mixture

### Explanation:
label: mixture
explanation: The story discusses the preliminary results of lapatinib (trade name Tykerb) and chemotherapy in HER-2 positive metastatic breast cancer patients. Patients who took lapatinib and the chemotherapy drug Xeloda remained stable (i.e. cancer did not spread further) nearly twice as long as patients who only had chemotherapy (8.5 months vs. 4.5 months). However, many drugs are effective in prolonging response in metastatic disease without impacting length of life. It would be good to get survival data to back up these claims, or at least provide data on quality of life to see whether the addition of lapatinib made a difference and how much. ### Context: The article discusses the new breast cancer screening guidelines issued by the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) and how they conflict with congressional action mandating insurance coverage for mammography screening. The article points out that while the USPSTF recommendations are aimed at women with an average risk of breast cancer, there are other factors that can place women at elevated risk, such as a history of prior breast surgery or certain genetic mutations. The article also mentions that there are varying estimates of the cost of a mammogram, with one paper from 2011 stating that the overall cost is $266. However, the article does not provide a clear answer on how much a mammogram would cost if it were not covered by insurance. 

The article notes that the USPSTF recommendations state that screening mammography has the greatest benefit for women ages 50 to 74, but it does not provide specific information on the potential benefits for different age groups. The article also briefly mentions the potential harms of over-diagnosis and false positives, but does not explain these terms or provide information on how serious these harms are or how common they are. 

The article does mention that women should be informed consumers and have the authority to weigh the potential benefits against the potential harms of mammography screening. It also discusses the recommendations from other organizations, such as the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists and the American Cancer Society, which have differing recommendations from the USPSTF. The article explains that mammograms have been used as breast cancer screening tools for a long time and discusses insurance coverage issues related to mammography screening. 

Overall, the article provides some information on the USPSTF recommendations and their implications, but it lacks specific details on the cost of mammograms without insurance coverage, the potential benefits for different age groups, and the seriousness and frequency of potential harms.
Claim: New breast cancer screening guidelines at odds with Congress
The claim veracity: true

### Explanation:
label: true
explanation: The story provides a good overview of new recommendations from the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) on when, and how often, women should receive mammograms to screen for breast cancer. The story summarizes the long-running debate over mammogram recommendations, particularly congressional action on the issue. The story also discusses the differing advice that various organizations provide on when women at average risk of breast cancer should begin mammogram screening, though the story would have been stronger if it had more fully explored both the benefits and potential harms associated with women starting mammogram screening early or having the tests more often (something that a competing New York Times story on the recommendations does well). The story also offers a good discussion of issues related to what the USPSTF recommendations may mean for insurance coverage of mammograms, though it does not tell readers how expensive mammograms may be without insurance. Breast cancer screening is a big deal. As the CDC notes, “Not counting some kinds of skin cancer, breast cancer in the United States is the most common cancer in women, no matter your race or ethnicity.” In 2012 alone, 41,150 women died of the disease. Breast cancer also has a profound impact on the economy, with researchers estimating that it costs the U.S. billions of dollars each year. In other words, it affects the health and well-being of millions of patients and their loved ones, as well as having an adverse impact on the economy. News that relates to the early detection and treatment of breast cancer is clearly news worth covering, particularly when it could inform the decision-making of women and health professionals — and have an effect on women’s access to screening.
claim: New breast cancer screening guidelines at odds with Congress
generated_result: The story does a good job of explaining the recommendations from the US Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) and how they differ from the recommendations of other groups. The story also does a good job of explaining the congressional action that mandated insurance coverage for mammography screening. The story could have been improved by providing more detail on the cost of a mammogram without insurance coverage, and by providing more detail on the potential benefits and harms of mammography. The story also could have been improved by providing more detail on the evidence that the USPSTF used to make their recommendations.
