### Context: The article discusses a news release about a phase Ib study that tested a combination of the drug Keytruda with an experimental agent called SD-101 for the treatment of advanced melanoma. The news release does not mention the cost of Keytruda, which is approximately $12,500 a month or $150,000 a year. The release also overstates the benefits of the treatment, suggesting that it could provide an alternative for patients whose tumors have not responded to other therapies. However, the study was not designed to test this and did not show such results. The focus of the study was on safety and dosage, but the news release does not provide any information about the symptoms or side effects experienced by the patients. The release describes the research as "early" and provides some information about the trial size and what was measured, but it fails to clarify that any assessment of benefit may be due to Keytruda alone. The release could have included statistics on the number of people diagnosed with metastatic melanoma each year. The study used a combination of Keytruda and SD-101, but it was not a head-to-head trial comparing the two. The release notes that the therapy is experimental and not yet available, but it could have mentioned that Keytruda was approved by the FDA for use in metastatic melanoma in 2015. The researchers in the study attempted to change the tumor microenvironment by injecting the experimental drug directly into the metastatic sites. The article criticizes the headline and subheadline of the news release for being wishful thinking and not based on the study's design or findings. There is no evidence to support the claim that the new treatment could help people with advanced melanoma live longer.
Claim: Combination approach shows promise for beating advanced melanoma
The claim veracity: mixture

### Explanation:
label: mixture
explanation: This news release describes a phase 1b trial to test whether injecting an immune stimulant directly into metastatic melanoma lesions would change the environment around the tumor in ways that would make an immunotherapy drug, pembrolizumab (Keytruda), more effective. But it’s important the readers are left primarily with the understanding that the results are from the dose-escalation phase–the part of a clinical trial where the researchers look to determine the “best” dose, typically meaning the highest dose that can be used without causing adverse symptoms or side effects. The study was not designed to see whether this approach was better than the approach currently used, or if it helped some people with metastatic melanoma live longer. Yet, the headline states: Combination approach shows promise for beating advanced melanoma. The sub-headline asserts, “the new treatment is more effective in people receiving immunotherapy for the first time.” And the first paragraph asserts that “a treatment that uses a bacteria-like agent in combination with an immunotherapy drug could help some people with advanced melanoma … live longer.” None of that is known yet. It also is notable that the release made no mention of side effects among patients given this combination of therapies–even though that’s what this trial was examining. Immunotherapy has seen some of its greatest success in the treatment of metastatic melanoma. But it doesn’t work in all patients. Scientists hope by learning why it doesn’t always work they can develop new types of immunotherapies, new combinations of immunotherapies or new ways to use immunotherapy drugs that will achieve the desired response: allowing people with metastatic melanoma to live longer. This news release describes a study that included 22 people, nine of whom were receiving an immunotherapy for the first time. Seven of those nine had “a positive response” to the drug combination. In two, the tumors disappeared completely. That’s a good thing. Would the patients have had the same response if they had received Keytruda alone? Maybe. Maybe not. There’s no way to know. The study wasn’t designed to test that. But this release could easily lead to news articles that make that case.
claim: Combination approach shows promise for beating advanced melanoma
generated_result: This news release describes a small, early-phase study of a combination of two drugs for the treatment of metastatic melanoma. The release does a good job of describing the study and the drug Keytruda, which is approved for the treatment of metastatic melanoma. However, the release overstates the benefits of the treatment, which were not part of the study’s design. The release also does not mention the cost of Keytruda, which is approximately $12,500 a month or $150,000 a year. The release could have included statistics on the number of people diagnosed with metastatic melanoma each year. The headline and subheadline are wishful thinking and not based on the study’s design or findings. There is no evidence to support the claim that the new treatment “could help people with advanced melanoma live longer.”

### Context: The claim that the COVID-19 pandemic was planned by the Rockefeller Foundation in "Operation Lockstep" is false. The rumor is based on a misinterpretation of a document published by the Rockefeller Foundation in 2010 called "Scenarios for the Future of Technology and International Development." This document envisioned four different scenarios, including one called "Lock Step," which dealt with a hypothetical global pandemic. However, the document does not provide any instructions on how to manufacture a pandemic.

The image circulating on social media titled "Operation Lockstep: From the Rockefeller Playbook" is not from a real document. The quote "Under the guise of a pandemic, we will create a prison state" does not appear in the actual document from the Rockefeller Foundation. This quote seems to come from a faulty interpretation of the document by a Wordpress blog.

The similarities between the "Lock Step" scenario in the document and the COVID-19 pandemic are few and far between. The hypothetical pandemic in the document started in 2012, originated in wild geese, and killed 8 million people in the first 7 months. In comparison, the COVID-19 pandemic began in late 2019, is believed to have originated with bats, and has killed over 600,000 people within a similar time frame. The document also envisioned that the majority of deaths would occur in Africa, Southeast Asia, and Central America, whereas the most deaths from COVID-19 have occurred in the United States.

The purpose of the Rockefeller Foundation's document was to explore different scenarios for the future of technology and international development in order to better prepare for potential challenges. It did not predict or plan for the COVID-19 pandemic.

In conclusion, the claim that the COVID-19 pandemic was planned by the Rockefeller Foundation in "Operation Lockstep" is based on misinformation and misinterpretation of a document. The document in question does not provide any instructions on how to manufacture a pandemic, and the similarities between the document's scenario and the COVID-19 pandemic are minimal.
Claim: The COVID-19 pandemic was planned by the Rockefeller Foundation in "Operation Lockstep.
The claim veracity: false

### Explanation:
label: false
explanation: This rumor is based on a 2010 report published by The Rockefeller Foundation entitled “Scenarios for the Future of Technology and International Development.” This document does not detail an “operation” in a “playbook” detailing how global elites can manufacture a pandemic and implement a prison state. Rather, this document explores the possible outcomes of four different scenarios.
claim: The COVID-19 pandemic was planned by the Rockefeller Foundation in "Operation Lockstep.
generated_result: What's true: A 2010 Rockefeller Foundation document envisioned a ""Lock Step"" scenario for a global pandemic. What's false: The document did not predict the COVID-19 pandemic, and it did not provide instructions on how to manufacture a pandemic.

As our understanding of various blood markers improves, our tests have become more specific and the ability to correctly diagnose patients in a shorter period of time has improved. The use of a more specific maker of heart muscle injury and heart attack is important. As independent physicians quoted in the story explain, a more sensitive test could save a lot of money, could help with many emergency decisions and treatment,  and may result in improved outcomes. Because of significant gaps in important details, this story misrepresents what the authors of the study concluded.

The new unit offers medication management, individual, group, and family therapy, and programs to teach healthy coping skills. The average patient will stay in the unit for three to five days, and most insurance plans are accepted. The unit is staffed by primary-care physicians, psychiatrists, psychiatric nurses, and social workers who address both medical and mental health issues. The unit has a calming color scheme and layout, resembling a high-end day spa. Patients have access to amenities such as a menu to select meals from and a nicely appointed day room. The staff at BRMC works to put together a discharge plan for each patient, including setting up outpatient therapy and follow-ups with the patient's primary care physician if needed.
Claim: New adult behavioral health unit opens in northern Arkansas.
The claim veracity: true

### Explanation:
label: true
explanation: The discussion of “mental health” seems to be a regular topic in the news these days.
claim: New adult behavioral health unit opens in northern Arkansas.
generated_result: A new 16-bed adult behavioral health center has opened in northern Arkansas to serve the region’s growing need for mental health care.

### Context: The claim that modern caesarean sections were invented by midwives in Africa is partially supported by historical accounts. An article from 1999 in the Archives of Disease in Childhood - Fetal and Neonatal Edition provides a historical and anecdotal account of a caesarean delivery in Uganda in 1879. The account was given by Robert Felkin, who witnessed the procedure and described it in a lecture to the Edinburgh Obstetrical Society in 1884. Felkin observed that the procedure was performed by men and used banana wine as an anesthetic. The patient was tied to a bed, and a midline incision was made in her abdomen. The uterus was massaged to contract, and the wound was closed with iron needles and dressed with a paste made from roots. The patient recovered well, although her milk production was delayed.

While this account supports the claim that caesarean sections were performed in Africa before they became standard elsewhere, it does not provide evidence that midwives specifically invented the procedure. The article also mentions that similar reports of successful caesarean sections in Africa come from Rwanda, where botanical preparations were used for anesthesia and wound healing.

The article further explains that in Western society, women were largely denied admission to medical schools until the late nineteenth century, which limited their ability to perform caesarean sections. However, there are records of a woman named James Miranda Stuart Barry performing a successful caesarean section in South Africa while masquerading as a man and serving as a physician to the British army.

The development of modern caesarean sections in Western medicine was influenced by advancements in anesthesia, antisepsis, and asepsis. The use of uterine sutures and transverse incisions in the lower segment of the uterus helped reduce the risk of infection and uterine rupture. The introduction of antibiotics after World War II further contributed to the prevalence of caesarean sections in labor and delivery.

Overall, while the historical account supports the claim that caesarean sections were performed in Africa before they became standard elsewhere, it does not specifically attribute the invention of the procedure to midwives. The article highlights the importance of advancements in anesthesia, antiseptic practices, and surgical techniques in the development of modern caesarean sections.
Claim: Modern caesarean sections were invented by midwives in Africa.
The claim veracity: unproven

### Explanation:
label: unproven
explanation: Were Modern Caesarean Sections Invented in Africa?
claim: Modern caesarean sections were invented by midwives in Africa.
generated_result: Were Caesarean Sections Invented by Midwives in Africa?

### Context: The article discusses a claim made by Reince Priebus, the Republican National Committee chairman, that Hillary Clinton took money from the kings of Saudi Arabia, Morocco, Oman, and Yemen. The article clarifies that while the Clinton Foundation has received donations from these countries, there is no evidence that Clinton herself personally benefited from the money. The Clinton Foundation is a global charity that partners with governments and non-government organizations to address issues such as AIDS and poverty. It has received millions of dollars from foreign governments, including Saudi Arabia, which has been a long-time partner of the United States in regional security and counterterrorism efforts. Oman, another donor to the foundation, has a military cooperation agreement with the US and plays a role in regional stability in the Middle East. Morocco, which donated to the foundation to hold a conference, is considered a strong partner in counterterrorism efforts by the US. However, the article notes that Yemen, which does not have a king, has not made any donations to the foundation. The article concludes that while Priebus' claim is partially accurate in terms of the countries that have donated to the Clinton Foundation, it is misleading to suggest that Clinton herself received the money.
Claim: Reince Priebus Says Hillary Clinton took "money from kings of Saudi Arabia and Morocco and Oman and Yemen.
The claim veracity: mixture

### Explanation:
label: mixture
explanation: Priebus said Clinton took "money from kings of Saudi Arabia and Morocco and Oman and Yemen." The monarchies of Saudi Arabia, Morocco and Oman have contributed to the Clinton Foundation, but Yemen, which does not have a king, has not. And although Priebus’ claim was made during a discussion of the foundation as well as contributions to political candidates, his phrasing could have left the impression that Clinton herself, rather than the foundation, received the money. For a statement that is partially accurate, our rating is Half True. To comment on this article, go to the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel's web page.
claim: Reince Priebus Says Hillary Clinton took "money from kings of Saudi Arabia and Morocco and Oman and Yemen.
generated_result: Priebus said Clinton took money from the kings of Saudi Arabia, Morocco, Oman and Yemen. The Clinton Foundation has received millions of dollars from Saudi Arabia, Oman and Morocco. Yemen, which does not have a king, has not donated to the foundation. But the money did not go to Clinton. The Clinton Foundation is a global charity that partners with governments and non-government organizations to address issues such as AIDS and poverty. The foundation has received millions of dollars from foreign governments, including Saudi Arabia, which has been a long-time partner of the United States in regional security and counterterrorism efforts. Oman, which donated to the foundation to hold a conference, is considered a strong partner in counterterrorism efforts by the United States. Morocco, which donated to the foundation to hold a conference, is considered a strong partner in counterterrorism efforts by the United States. The claim is partially accurate but is misleading to suggest that Clinton herself received the money.

### Context: The claim is about a photograph showing a dead man whose co-workers took a selfie with him, thinking he was sleeping. The article explains that the claim is based on a screenshot of a headline that was shared on a Facebook page. However, no related article or source was provided. A search for the headline did not yield any results, suggesting that it may be old or non-existent.

The attached image, however, has a different story. It was originally shared on Reddit in 2016 on the r/PSBattles subreddit, where users were encouraged to edit the photo of a man sleeping in front of his co-workers. The same image also appeared on Reddit's r/TIFU subreddit, but that post has since been deleted.

On February 3, 2016, the Huffington Post covered the viral sensation of the sleeping man. The man in the photo was identified as Eduard Paraschivescu, an intern in Montreal, Canada. He had fallen asleep at his desk during training at a company called Gsoft. When he woke up, his co-workers were laughing and taking pictures and videos of him. He also received a message asking him to bring doughnuts the next day. Paraschivescu himself posted the photo on Reddit, where it gained attention on the PhotoshopBattles subreddit.

The article explains that the screenshot of the headline, "Man suffers heart attack, dies at work, coworkers gather for group selfie thinking he'd fallen asleep," is an example of how "fake news" items are created. The viral photo of the sleeping intern from 2016 was paired with an untrue headline reflecting an old urban legend about an office worker who remained dead and unnoticed at their desk for five days. This previous viral claim highlighted fears that employees are seen as disposable by their employers. The article concludes by mentioning that the original photograph gained popularity on various subreddits before becoming a viral hit on its own in 2016.

In summary, the claim about the photograph showing a dead man whose co-workers took a selfie with him is based on a screenshot of a headline that lacks a related article or source. The attached image is actually of a sleeping intern from 2016, and the original photograph gained popularity on Reddit before becoming a viral hit.
Claim: A photograph shows a dead man whose unwitting co-workers arranged a "funny selfie," believing he was just sleeping.
The claim veracity: false

### Explanation:
label: false
explanation: Did a Man’s Co-Workers Inadvertently Pose with a ‘Sleeping’ Corpse?
claim: A photograph shows a dead man whose unwitting co-workers arranged a "funny selfie," believing he was just sleeping.
generated_result: What's true: A photograph shows a man sleeping at his desk. What's false: The man in the photograph was dead, and his co-workers took a ""funny selfie"" without realizing he was deceased.

### Context: According to an article, Democratic gubernatorial candidate Mary Burke claimed that under Governor Scott Walker's policies, the typical Wisconsin worker makes $5,000 less each year than workers in Minnesota. The article examines this claim and finds that it is accurate. The article cites three different sources that all show Minnesota workers earning more than Wisconsin workers. According to survey-based estimates from the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, the annual average wage of Minnesota workers in May 2013 was $47,370, which is $5,060 higher than the $42,310 figure for Wisconsin. Additionally, average earnings per job in 2012 were $53,928 in Minnesota, $4,931 more than Wisconsin's $48,997, according to the U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis. When excluding proprietor's income and focusing on regular salaries and wages, the gap between the two states is $5,757 in Minnesota's favor. The article also notes that the wage gap between Minnesota and Wisconsin has existed since at least the 1960s and has gradually grown over time. While experts agree that a governor's actions have a limited effect on a state's economy, Burke's claim that Walker's policies are linked to the wage gap is supported by the fact that the gap did not narrow in Walker's first two years in office. The article concludes that while the gap has grown or held steady under Walker's policies, it is a longstanding disparity that existed and grew under governors of both political parties. Therefore, the claim made by Burke is rated as accurate.
Claim: The typical Wisconsin worker makes $5,000 less each year than our neighbors in Minnesota" under Gov. Scott Walker’s policies.
The claim veracity: true

### Explanation:
label: true
explanation: Burke told delegates at the state Democratic convention that "the typical Wisconsin worker makes $5,000 less each year than our neighbors in Minnesota" under Walker’s policies. The gap is real and Burke hit the mark with her description of it. The gap has grown or held steady in Walker’s time depending on the measuring stick used. Burke didn’t say Walker created the gap, but the disparity is a longstanding one, and one that existed and grew under governors of both political stripes.
claim: The typical Wisconsin worker makes $5,000 less each year than our neighbors in Minnesota" under Gov. Scott Walker’s policies.
generated_result: Burke said the ""typical Wisconsin worker makes $5,000 less each year than our neighbors in Minnesota."" That’s a reference to the gap in average wages between the two states. The gap has grown or held steady under Walker, but it’s a longstanding disparity that grew or held steady under governors of both political parties. Burke’s claim is that Walker’s policies are linked to the gap. Experts say a governor’s actions have a limited effect on a state’s economy. But Burke’s claim is supported by the fact that the gap didn’t narrow in Walker’s first two years in office. Burke’s claim is accurate, but needs a qualifier.

### Context: A Facebook post claimed that a series of 11 photos were from the 1918 flu pandemic. However, a fact-checking investigation found that only five of the photos were actually from that time period. The first photo, featuring two women with bags over their heads, was actually taken in 1953 during a smog and smoke event in Philadelphia. Another photo of women in gas masks tending to a stroller was from a gas test during World War II in 1941. An advertisement for Bell Telephone Co. that mentioned quarantine and the sick was not connected to the 1918 pandemic, but rather existed as early as 1910. An image of an ad encouraging people to stay home was created in 2020 in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. A photo of two women wearing masks while visiting over a car window was taken in 1929 during a separate flu epidemic. 

However, there were five photos that were indeed from the 1918 influenza pandemic. One photo showed a woman wearing a mask in February 1919, following the First World War. Another photo depicted a sign on a streetcar that read "Spit spreads death," taken in October 1918 in Philadelphia. An image of rows of beds used for treating flu patients during the 1918 pandemic was also confirmed to be from that time period. A photo of a masked newsboy outside a closed theater during the influenza pandemic was taken between October 5 and November 11, 1918. Lastly, a news announcement featuring a Red Cross nurse wearing a mask was legitimately from 1918.

In conclusion, while the Facebook post claimed that all 11 photos were from the 1918 flu pandemic, only five of them were actually from that time period. The other six photos were from different events and time periods, including World War II, a separate flu epidemic in 1929, and the current COVID-19 pandemic.
Claim: Facebook post Says series of 11 photos are “from the 1918 flu pandemic.”
The claim veracity: false

### Explanation:
label: false
explanation: Five of the 11 photos are from the 1918 flu pandemic. Six are not.
claim: Facebook post Says series of 11 photos are “from the 1918 flu pandemic.”
generated_result: Five of the photos were from the 1918 flu pandemic. Six were from other events.

### Context: The claim that Splenda is unsafe for human consumption is not supported by scientific evidence. Sucralose, the artificial sweetener in Splenda, has undergone extensive safety testing and has been approved by regulatory agencies in multiple countries. Studies have shown that sucralose is well-tolerated by humans and does not have any significant risks associated with its consumption. The claim that only two human studies were conducted on sucralose is false, as there have been over 100 scientific studies conducted on its safety. The idea that sucralose is "unnatural" and therefore unsafe is also unfounded, as sucralose is a non-caloric sweetener that is derived from sugar but has been chemically altered to make it non-metabolizable. The claim that sucralose can cause seizures, dizziness, migraines, allergic reactions, weight gain, blurred vision, and gastrointestinal issues is based on anecdotal reports and has not been confirmed by scientific studies. The lawsuit between the manufacturers of Splenda and Equal over false advertising claims is outdated and irrelevant to the safety of sucralose. The recent study that purportedly linked Splenda to cancer in mice has been criticized for its methodology and dissonant findings, and regulatory agencies have stated that the conclusions of the study are not supported by the data. Overall, the safety and effectiveness of sucralose have been well-supported by scientific research, and it is considered safe for human consumption.
Claim: The artificial sweetener Splenda was inadequately tested and is unsafe for human consumption.
The claim veracity: false

### Explanation:
label: false
explanation: Claims that the artificial sweetener Splenda was inadequately tested and is unsafe for human consumption are at odds with numerous scientific studies.
claim: The artificial sweetener Splenda was inadequately tested and is unsafe for human consumption.
generated_result: What's true: A 2017 study found that mice fed a sucralose-laden diet had a higher incidence of colonic tumors. What's false: The study has been criticized for its methodology and conclusions, and the FDA and EFSA have determined that sucralose is safe for human consumption.

The claims made by Higgins in her post are generally accurate. She emphasized that COVID-19 is more lethal than the seasonal flu, with a mortality rate of about 3% compared to 0.1% for the flu. Italy has implemented strict measures to contain the virus, including travel restrictions, closures of nonessential businesses, and social distancing. The country's healthcare system is overwhelmed, with over 80% of hospital beds in the hardest-hit province occupied by COVID-19 patients. Doctors are struggling to meet patients' needs and are even rationing care.

The article also highlights the importance of young people taking precautions, as they can catch and spread the virus to more vulnerable populations. The goal is to minimize the number of people each sick person infects through measures like school closures and event cancellations.

The full text of Higgins' Facebook post is included in the article, where she urges individuals to change their behavior to limit contagion and prevent their own countries from experiencing the same crisis as Italy.

Overall, the article confirms the authenticity of Higgins' post and verifies the accuracy of her claims about the severity of the COVID-19 crisis in Italy.

### Context: The article discusses a form of strep throat called invasive Group A Streptococcal Disease (iGAS) that can infect the nasal passage, sinuses, face, and even other organs. It explains that while most cases of strep throat and other strep infections are relatively mild, sometimes the bacteria can become invasive and cause more serious and potentially life-threatening infections. Symptoms of an iGAS infection can include fever, chills, sore throat, dizziness, confusion, severe pain, and redness or swelling around a wound or injured area. In severe cases, iGAS can lead to conditions such as necrotizing fasciitis (commonly known as a "flesh-eating disease"), myositis, myonecrosis, and Streptococcal Toxic Shock Syndrome (StrepTSS), which can result in total organ failure.

The article mentions a cautionary tale shared by an Idaho couple on Facebook about their son's strange mark on his face, which was ultimately diagnosed as a form of strep throat that infects the sinuses. It highlights that iGAS infections often occur in clusters and affect groups more likely to be immunocompromised, but recent research suggests that adults and children of any age and in any medical condition can contract the disease. However, severe iGAS infections remain quite rare.

The article also mentions that outbreaks of iGAS have occurred in closed environments such as nursing homes and hospitals. It states that while many initial reports of iGAS described cases in adults, children are also affected by the infection. It provides examples of the incidence of invasive streptococcal disease in different populations, such as a small Minnesota community where 26 cases per 100,000 population were recorded and children in Utah where the incidence reached 14 cases per 100,000 population.

In summary, the article confirms the claim that a form of strep infection is capable of affecting the nasal cavity and face. It provides information about invasive Group A Streptococcal Disease (iGAS), its symptoms, potential complications, and its occurrence in different populations. It emphasizes that while severe iGAS infections are rare, they can be life-threatening and require immediate medical treatment.
Claim: A form of strep infection is capable of affecting the nasal cavity and face.
The claim veracity: true

### Explanation:
label: true
explanation: In the case of the Idaho family, iGAS was diagnosed in time, and the pictured boy was reportedly recovering well.
claim: A form of strep infection is capable of affecting the nasal cavity and face.
generated_result: Is a Strep Infection Capable of Affecting the Nasal Cavity and Face?

### Context: The article discusses a viral Facebook post that claims N95 masks, surgical masks, and cloth masks are ineffective in protecting against the spread of COVID-19. The post selectively cites recommendations from the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). 

Regarding N95 masks, the post claims that when exhaling through an N95 respirator, the design allows potentially infectious breath to be exhaled without filtration. This claim is mostly true, but it only applies to N95 respirators with valves. Masks with valves were designed for construction/factory workers or miners to keep out dust and particles, not to prevent infectious particles from leaving the mask. The San Francisco Department of Public Health has stated that N95 masks with valves are not safe and may actually propel germs further. Hospitals primarily use N95 masks without valves, and OSHA guidelines focus on their ability to prevent workers from inhaling small particles.

The post also claims that surgical masks are ineffective and can make the wearer a "walking virus dispenser." While OSHA guidelines state that surgical masks protect against potentially infectious splashes and sprays and contain the wearer's respiratory droplets, they offer ineffective protection against transmission via airborne particles due to their loose fit. The post suggests that surgical masks should be changed or thrown out every 20-30 minutes, but OSHA simply recommends proper disposal after use.

Regarding cloth masks, the post claims that they do not filter anything and can make the wearer sicker. It suggests that the moisture caught in cloth masks can lead to mildew and cause symptoms such as dry coughing and enhanced allergies. However, OSHA guidelines already state that cloth masks are ineffective filters against airborne particles. They are worn to protect others from respiratory droplets, and wearing them does not pose a significant risk of breathing in unhealthy amounts of carbon dioxide. OSHA and CDC recommend washing cloth masks after use to prevent the danger of dirty masks.

In conclusion, the Facebook post is correct in stating that N95 masks, surgical masks, and cloth masks can be dangerous and/or ineffective in protecting against the spread of COVID-19, based on CDC and OSHA guidelines. However, it is important to note that the effectiveness and recommendations vary depending on the type of mask.
Claim: A Facebook post is correct in saying N95 masks, surgical masks, and cloth masks can be dangerous and/or ineffective in protecting against the spread of COVID-19 based on CDC and U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) guidelines. 
The claim veracity: false

### Explanation:
label: false
explanation: What's true: N95 respirators with valves do allow unfiltered exhaled air to reach others, increasing the risk of spreading infection. Cloth and surgical masks do not protect the wearer from airborne infection. Cloth masks also get dirty easily, which is why OSHA and CDC recommend regular washing. What's false: However, contrary to the posts, OSHA and CDC have not recommended against wearing face coverings of any kind. Also contrary to the posts, cloth and surgical masks are not entirely ineffective because they prevent the wearer from transmitting infection to others through droplets. Surgical masks also protect wearers from getting potential infections via droplets. In addition, people who wear these masks are in little to no danger of breathing in too much carbon dioxide.
claim: A Facebook post is correct in saying N95 masks, surgical masks, and cloth masks can be dangerous and/or ineffective in protecting against the spread of COVID-19 based on CDC and U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) guidelines.
generated_result: What's true: N95 masks with valves, surgical masks, and cloth masks can be dangerous and/or ineffective in protecting against the spread of COVID-19, according to CDC and OSHA guidelines. What's false: However, the Facebook post's claims are misleading, as the effectiveness of each mask type varies.

### Context: The article examines the claim made by Hillary Clinton that "we are seeing kids who are healthier" and assesses the validity of this statement. The article acknowledges that there is no single agreed-upon measure for children's health, but focuses on obesity rates and nutrition as indicators.

Regarding obesity rates, the article states that there are some signs of improvement among children aged 11 and under, but not among older children. However, the article cautions that these improvements are not significant and that there are no continued increases, especially among young children.

In terms of nutrition, the government's Healthy Eating Index shows an increase from 49.5 in 2005-06 to 55.1 in 2011-12 for children aged 2-17. However, the article quotes an obesity researcher who is skeptical that improving nutrition alone will improve obesity rates. Additionally, the article notes that it would take a long time to see any effect on obesity rates nationally.

The article also examines other measures of children's health that fall outside of Michelle Obama's work on nutrition and exercise. The Federal Interagency Forum on Child and Family Statistics reports negative trends in adolescent depression, limited activities due to chronic conditions, and asthma rates among children. However, the article acknowledges that there have been dramatic reductions in mortality rates among all children since 1990, with greater declines among poor children, indicating a decrease in inequality in mortality.

In conclusion, the article states that while there are some improvements in obesity rates among younger children and better nutrition according to the Healthy Eating Index, there are negative trends in other measures of children's health. The article suggests that there are longer-term gains in children's health, particularly in terms of mortality rates and reductions in drug and alcohol abuse and teen pregnancy rates. Overall, the article suggests that the claim made by Hillary Clinton is not entirely accurate, as there are both positive and negative trends in children's health.
Claim: We are seeing kids who are healthier.
The claim veracity: mixture

### Explanation:
label: mixture
explanation: Clinton said that "we are seeing kids who are healthier." She said that in the context of First Lady Obama’s work on nutrition and exercise, and her campaign staff drew our attention to obesity trends. The latest numbers show less obesity for kids 11 and under, but a continued rise for young teens 12 to 17. As for diet, the government’s index for healthy eating has gone up. On the flip side, several measures such as depression, asthma and curtailed activity are moving in the wrong direction. At best, in the areas that lie at the heart of the first lady’s work, the picture is mixed.
claim: We are seeing kids who are healthier.
generated_result: Clinton said, ""We are seeing kids who are healthier."" There are some signs of improvement among children aged 11 and under, but not among older children. The improvements are not significant, and there are no continued increases, especially among young children. The government’s Healthy Eating Index shows a slight improvement in nutrition, but an expert we reached out to was skeptical that improving nutrition alone will improve obesity rates. The claim is partially accurate, but leaves out important details.

### Context: Democratic Gov. Gina Raimondo of Rhode Island has signed a new law that requires public colleges and universities in the state to establish a plan for addressing students' mental health needs promptly. The law discourages relying solely on off-campus services and aims to prevent suicides at higher education institutions. According to the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention, Rhode Island is now one of 11 states with a law addressing suicide prevention in higher education.

However, the University of Rhode Island (URI), Rhode Island College, and Community College of Rhode Island (CCRI) do not currently have suicide prevention policies that meet the new requirement. While these institutions offer counseling and mental health services, they need to develop formal policies on suicide prevention. URI has assured lawmakers that it is well-prepared to implement the provisions of the legislation and has existing resources and systems in place to respond to student concerns. CCRI is currently working on a formal policy on suicide prevention, and Rhode Island College's counseling center director, Chantelle Pseekos, supports any requirement that promotes student safety and destigmatizes mental health services.

The new law will prompt schools to review their mental health services and identify any gaps. The nonprofit Jed Foundation, which works to prevent suicide among teenagers and young adults, believes that the law will encourage schools to consider what they can provide on campus rather than relying solely on community providers. This approach is expected to make seeking help for mental health issues more normalized.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) reported in June that suicide rates have been increasing in almost every state. In Rhode Island, the suicide rate rose by approximately 34% from 1999 to 2016. The new law requires schools to present their plans, along with any new policies and training being implemented, to legislative leaders and the Rhode Island Council on Postsecondary Education by January 1.

Overall, the new law in Rhode Island aims to prevent suicides at public colleges and universities by requiring institutions to establish plans for addressing students' mental health needs promptly. It encourages schools to develop on-campus services and aims to destigmatize mental health services. The law comes in response to rising suicide rates in the state and across the country.
Claim: Rhode Island law aims to prevent suicides at public colleges.
The claim veracity: true

### Explanation:
label: true
explanation: Rhode Island is the latest state to require public colleges to do more to prevent suicides.
claim: Rhode Island law aims to prevent suicides at public colleges.
generated_result: Rhode Island has become the 11th state to require colleges and universities to have a suicide prevention policy.

### Context: The article discusses the claim made by United States Attorney General Jeff Sessions that there is a link between legalized marijuana and violence. Sessions stated that his conversations with Nebraska Attorney General Douglas Peterson, who is concerned about marijuana flowing in from Colorado, helped bring this issue to his attention. However, the article argues that both claims lack credible data to support these assertions.

The article mentions that Peterson and Oklahoma Attorney General Scott Pruitt attempted to seek permission from the United States Supreme Court to sue the state of Colorado over alleged increases in crime. The filing alleged that marijuana from Colorado was entering Nebraska in higher numbers since legalization, but no empirical evidence has been introduced to demonstrate that this marijuana has led to any increase in drug-trade related violence in Nebraska.

The article also discusses a report by the Rocky Mountain High Intensity Drug Trafficking Area Program, which raised concerns about various issues related to marijuana legalization in Colorado, including increased crime rates. However, the report itself states that the data reported does not infer that the data is due to the legalization of marijuana.

The article then mentions a study published in the journal PLOS One, which investigated changes to crime rates in states before and after the legalization of medical marijuana. The study found no evidence of a crime exacerbating effect of medical marijuana legalization and suggested that it may be correlated with a reduction in homicide and assault rates.

Another study presented at a conference found that medical marijuana legalization led to a significant decrease in arrest rates for violent crimes among both juveniles and adults. A study published in the Journal of Drug Issues also found no evidence of negative spillover effects from medical marijuana laws on violent or property crime.

The article concludes that the arguments attempting to make connections between marijuana legalization and violent crime lack credible evidence. It suggests that the claim made by Sessions is similar to speculative fears that have historically been used in campaigns against ending federal marijuana prohibition.
Claim: There is a demonstrable link between marijuana legalization and an increase in violent crime.
The claim veracity: false

### Explanation:
label: false
explanation: Conjecture aside, no credible data exists that supports a significant association between increased violent crime and marijuana legalization. Furthermore, studies suggest that — so far — violent crime decreases in states with legalized medical marijuana. Until new research credibly suggests otherwise, the claim that a demonstrable link between the two exists will remain classified as false.
claim: There is a demonstrable link between marijuana legalization and an increase in violent crime.
generated_result: What's true: A report from the Rocky Mountain High Intensity Drug Trafficking Area Program raised concerns about crime rates in Colorado after marijuana was legalized. What's false: The report did not claim that marijuana was the cause of the crime rate increases, and there is no credible evidence that marijuana legalization has led to an increase in violent crime.

### Context: Drumming classes, such as Pound and Drums Alive, offer effective workouts for people of all ages and fitness levels. These classes combine conditioning moves and cardio interval training with the fun of drumming. Pound, created by Kirsten Potenza and Cristina Peerenboom, is a 45-minute class that includes intensive cardio and ab work. Participants spend about 40% of the time standing, 40% seated, and 10% on their backs. Dr. J. Timothy Lightfoot, director of the Sydney and JL Huffines Institute for Sports Medicine and Human Performance at Texas A&M University, believes drumming is a physiologically taxing activity that can burn around 400 calories in a workout. Drumming engages all extremities simultaneously, making it a unique form of exercise. Drums Alive, created by Carrie Ekins, combines aerobic dance and drumming and is popular in senior centers as well as gyms. The program offers sitting programs for those who can't stand and programs for kindergartens and schools. Drumming workouts are accessible to people of all ages and fitness levels, with a learning curve that can be overcome in a few months. Unlike other classes that require a certain level of fitness or experience, drumming classes can be enjoyed by anyone.
Claim: For a full-body workout, drumming is the novelty to beat.
The claim veracity: true

### Explanation:
label: true
explanation: Drumsticks, pounded on gym floors, clinked overhead and bounced on exercise balls, are among the latest workout tools to tap into the group fitness scene, according to fitness experts.
claim: For a full-body workout, drumming is the novelty to beat.
generated_result: For a full-body workout, drumming is the novelty to beat.

### Context: A new study has shown promising results for two experimental Ebola vaccines. The study, conducted by the US and Liberian governments, as well as other organizations including GlaxoSmithKline and Merck, found that both vaccines were able to increase a person's antibody response to the Ebola virus. However, the study was not able to determine if the vaccines actually prevent the disease, as it did not have enough time to see if the vaccines prevented sickness and death from Ebola. The study also found that the level of serious adverse events was higher in the placebo group than in either vaccine group, with most of the serious adverse events attributed to malaria. The article notes that there is currently no proven successful treatment against Ebola, so the availability of an Ebola vaccine would be important to address. The article also mentions that readers would want to know if the vaccines will actually prevent the disease, and while the study showed increased antibody levels, it did not determine the level of antibody response needed for protection. The article provides useful context by mentioning that the study was the first placebo-controlled study of two vaccines against the Ebola virus, and that the vaccines were developed by pharmaceutical companies. However, it does not mention that several of the researchers have economic ties to these companies. Overall, the article does a good job of summarizing the study's findings and putting them in context, but it could have addressed the potential cost and limitations of the vaccines, as well as the possibility of using them in the event of a new epidemic.
Claim: Ebola Vaccines Show Promise in New Study
The claim veracity: true

### Explanation:
label: true
explanation: This Wall Street Journal story reports on a New England Journal of Medicine-published study of the trial of two potential vaccines against Ebola disease. Overall, it’s a brief but well-constructed article on a much anticipated study of two Ebola candidate vaccines. Independent sourcing helps bolster the piece, and so does the detailed explanation of the current study. Readers are told how these findings fit in with the larger body of work developing a vaccine. That said, we think the story would have been stronger had it been more clear on the industry connections behind the study, and if it had discussed availability of the vaccine–especially if a new outbreak occurs. Vaccine development for Ebola would be a big step forward in combatting a deadly infection. And it can be tempting for journalists to get caught up in the exciting research developments, but as we’ve discussed, journalists and consumers need to immunize themselves against hype about unproven vaccines. This story takes a balanced approach by pointing out limitations of the current research.
claim: Ebola Vaccines Show Promise in New Study
generated_result: This is a story about a study of two experimental Ebola vaccines. The story does a good job of describing the study and its findings. The story could have been improved by addressing the potential cost and limitations of the vaccines, and by reminding readers that the vaccines have not been proven to prevent the disease. The story also could have addressed the possibility of using these vaccines in the event of a new epidemic. The story does a good job of putting the study in context by mentioning that it was the first placebo-controlled study of two vaccines against the Ebola virus, and that the vaccines were developed by pharmaceutical companies. The story also could have mentioned that several of the researchers have economic ties to these companies.

### Context: The article discusses a claim made by the Facebook page "Live Action" that Planned Parenthood lies about providing prenatal care. The video presented by Live Action quotes snippets from speeches by Cecile Richards, the president of Planned Parenthood, and Lori Lamerand, the CEO of Planned Parenthood of Mid and South Michigan, to support their claim. However, the article explains that these quotes were taken out of context. Richards was listing various services provided by Planned Parenthood, not claiming they offer only or primarily prenatal care. Lamerand's quote was also taken out of context from a speech where she spoke about vital services like birth control and cancer screenings.

The article points out that although Planned Parenthood does provide prenatal care services, it is not a primary part of their operation. According to their annual report, they provided 17,419 instances of prenatal care services compared to over 3 million STD tests and over 300,000 abortions. The article also states that Live Action's claim that only 5 out of 97 Planned Parenthood facilities provide prenatal care is misleading. There are many Planned Parenthood clinics that advertise prenatal services, and even those that do not provide prenatal care offer resources to assist patients in finding such care.

The article highlights that Live Action's video is based on the implication that Planned Parenthood claimed to provide prenatal care services at all of their facilities, which is not the case. A spokesperson for Planned Parenthood stated that not every single one of their health centers provides prenatal care, and they have never said otherwise. The organization's website states that their health centers focus on prevention, with 80% of their patients receiving services to prevent unintended pregnancy.

The article concludes by noting that Live Action chose to compare the number of prenatal services provided by Planned Parenthood to the number of abortions, giving the misleading impression that Planned Parenthood rarely provides reproductive health services other than abortions. In reality, Planned Parenthood provides more STD screenings, contraception services, and cancer screenings than they do abortions.
Claim: A video investigation showed that Planned Parenthood lies about providing prenatal care.
The claim veracity: false

### Explanation:
label: false
explanation: What's true: Prenatal care makes up a small portion of Planned Parenthood's services, and not all Planned Parenthood affiliates offer these services. What's false: Planned Parenthood offers a number of reproductive health services other than abortion -- including prenatal care (and referrals to prenatal care providers) -- at multiple health centers across the U.S. and has not claimed to offer prenatal care at all their centers.
claim: A video investigation showed that Planned Parenthood lies about providing prenatal care.
generated_result: What's true: Planned Parenthood does provide prenatal care services. What's false: Planned Parenthood does not claim to provide prenatal care at all of its facilities, and it does not claim to provide prenatal care more often than abortions.

prompt:
### Context: A nurse at Children's Mercy Hospital in Kansas City, Missouri, named Christa Jordan wanted to donate her kidney to her friend and patient, Dayshanae Hosman, who has a genetic condition called Alagille syndrome and went on dialysis in April. However, the University of Kansas Hospital found an even better match for Hosman, a 25-year-old altruistic donor named Ky Kanaman. Jordan was then informed that she was a better match for a person on the transplant list named Lauro Zuniga, whom she didn't know. Jordan agreed to give her kidney to Zuniga if Kanaman donated his to Hosman, thus starting a kidney donation chain.

Carolina Perez, Zuniga's mother, was not a match for her son. However, when Jordan agreed to give her kidney to Zuniga, Perez discovered that she could donate one of her kidneys to a stranger on the university hospital's list named Matt Lewis. This created a chain of kidney donations, with each donor giving to a recipient they didn't know.

Donation chains like this are rare and require extensive planning by hospitals. It starts with a donor wanting to give to someone they aren't a good match with. The hospital then finds a recipient that the donor matches with but doesn't know, sparking conversations to find the best donor-recipient matches.

On October 29 and 30, six surgeries were conducted at the two hospitals involved. The three donors and three recipients finally got together at Children's Mercy, with many meeting for the first time. Matt Lewis, one of the recipients, expressed his gratitude and said, "I feel like I won the lottery."

Overall, this article highlights the story of Christa Jordan, a nurse who wanted to donate her kidney to her friend and patient. However, due to a better match being found, a kidney donation chain was initiated, involving multiple donors and recipients. The article emphasizes the rarity of donation chains and the extensive planning required by hospitals to ensure successful matches.
Claim: Nurse’s kidney donation triggers bi-state transplant chain.
The claim veracity: true

### Explanation:
label: true
explanation: A nurse’s decision to donate a kidney to a patient triggered a series of events that led to three people getting new organs at two Kansas City-area hospitals.
claim: Nurse’s kidney donation triggers bi-state transplant chain.
generated_result: A kidney donation by a Kansas City, Kansas, nurse for a friend in Kansas City, Missouri, started a six-way transplant chain that involved hospitals in both cities.

### Context: Novartis is hopeful for its novel heart drug, canakinumab, despite its "modest" benefit. The drug was tested on heart attack survivors and was found to reduce the risk of another major cardiac event by 15% compared to a placebo. However, the article points out that the study did not provide the absolute numbers of events, only the events per 100 person-years. In the placebo group, there were 4.50 cardiac events per 100 person-years, while in the group receiving 150 mg doses of canakinumab, there were 3.86 events per 100 person-years. The 150 mg dose was the only statistically significant result, specifically for non-fatal heart attacks. The article also mentions that the study did not discuss the harms of the drug in depth, such as the frequency and severity of side effects. 

The article highlights that there are concerns about the high cost of the drug and potential fatal infection risks. It mentions that there are other effective and less expensive alternatives for secondary cardiac disease prevention, such as smoking cessation, aspirin, statins, and blood pressure control. Despite these concerns, Novartis plans to seek regulatory approval for the drug's use against heart disease.

The article acknowledges that the drug has novel effects and targeting, but it does not rely on the news release. It includes commentary from a drug industry analyst and the study's accompanying editorial. The article also notes that the drug industry's research costs are often opaque, making it important to explain the realities of medicine's pricing system to the public.

Overall, the article provides a balanced view of the potential benefits and concerns surrounding Novartis' novel heart drug. It emphasizes the need for transparency in pricing and the importance of considering alternative treatments.
Claim: Novartis hopeful for novel heart drug, despite 'modest' benefit
The claim veracity: true

### Explanation:
label: true
explanation: In contrast to the TIME article on this study (which we reviewed), and some others, the Reuters piece is appropriately skeptical and far more business-oriented, paying substantial detail to costs, harms, and regulatory challenges and cautions. It is skimpier than than the TIME article on some of the biological novelty of the new drug, but overall does a better job of informing readers and professionals of the slow slog many novel drugs must take before they are demonstrated safe, effective and affordable for those who may benefit. The anti-inflammatory scientific arc is littered with the consequences of less-than-stellar clinical results, overblown expectations and pharmaceutical industry high-stakes business gambles. That makes it especially important for news organizations to cover the subject area with the utmost care and context–this story took pains to do so.
claim: Novartis hopeful for novel heart drug, despite 'modest' benefit
generated_result: This is a story about a drug that has been tested in a large group of people who have had a heart attack. The drug, canakinumab, is a monoclonal antibody that is thought to reduce inflammation. The story does a good job of explaining the study, the potential harms of the drug, and the cost of the drug. The story could have been improved by including the absolute numbers of events, not just the numbers per 100 person-years. The story also could have been improved by including the cost of other treatments for secondary cardiac disease prevention. The story does a good job of explaining the realities of medicine’s pricing system.

### Context: The article fact-checks a claim made by CNN commentator Van Jones during a discussion about institutional racism in law enforcement. Jones stated that African-Americans don't use drugs at a higher level than whites but end up going to prison six times more often. The article investigates the validity of this claim.

The article references a 2014 National Research Council report that states there is little difference in drug use between blacks and whites. The report also mentions that drug-related arrest rates for blacks have been three to four times higher than those for whites in recent years.

To determine the rates of imprisonment for drug crimes, the article turns to data from the Bureau of Justice Statistics and the United States Sentencing Commission. Adjusting for the number of blacks and whites, the black imprisonment rate for drug offenses is about 5.8 times higher than it is for whites. This aligns closely with Jones' claim.

The article also mentions a statistic from the NAACP's Criminal Justice Fact Sheet, which asserts that African-Americans are sent to prison for drug offenses at 10 times the rate of whites. However, the source for this statistic is not provided, and it may be outdated.

The article explores possible reasons for the disparity in drug-related imprisonment rates. One reason is that blacks are more likely to get caught selling drugs in public, making them easier targets for arrest. Additionally, blacks arrested for drugs are more likely to have a previous criminal record, which can result in longer sentences.

In conclusion, the article finds that African-Americans do not use drugs at a higher level than whites, and the rate of their incarceration for drug offenses is very close to what Jones claimed. The article rates Jones' claim as true.
Claim: African-Americans don't use drugs at a higher level than whites but "wind up going to prison six times more.
The claim veracity: true

### Explanation:
label: true
explanation: Jones said that African-Americans don't use drugs at a higher level than whites but wind up going to prison six times more. African-Americans use drugs at roughly the same levels as white Americans, although overall illicit drug use among blacks has been marginally higher than for whites, with some differences in the types of drugs used, according to a national surveys. Jones' bigger point was about the disparity in sentencing, and the rate of African-Americans' incarceration for drug offenses is very close to what Jones said.
claim: African-Americans don't use drugs at a higher level than whites but "wind up going to prison six times more.
generated_result: Jones said that African-Americans don't use drugs at a higher level than whites but ""wind up going to prison six times more."" The rate of their incarceration for drug offenses is very close to what he said. The one caveat is that the source for the 10-times statistic is not clear, and it may be outdated.

### Context: The article criticizes a news release about a study that claims omega-3 fatty acid supplements may lower breast cancer risk in postmenopausal obese women. The release fails to mention the cost of the supplements, which can be expensive for most Americans. It also does not provide specific information on how much the supplement may lower a woman's risk or mention any potential harms or side effects. The release presents the findings of a small subgroup as if they were the main results of the study, without mentioning that the original study did not find a difference in breast density changes in any of the treatment arms. The significant result was only found in women with a BMI greater than 29. The release also inaccurately states the number of women who completed the clinical trial and the number of groups they were divided into. It fails to mention that other trials have found that the drug Raloxifene does not have an effect on breast density. The release does not mention any other approaches to reducing breast cancer risk, such as limiting alcohol, not smoking, controlling weight, breastfeeding, and exercising. It does note that the supplement used in the study, Lovaza, is FDA approved and requires a prescription. The release does not provide any evidence of novelty and fails to provide data to back up the claim that omega-3 fatty acids may reduce breast cancer risk.
Claim: Omega-3 Fatty Acids May Lower Breast Cancer Risk in Postmenopausal Obese Women
The claim veracity: mixture

### Explanation:
label: mixture
explanation: This release describes the results of a study testing whether omega-3 fatty acids have a beneficial effect on reducing the risk of breast cancer in obese women by reducing the density of their breast tissue. Higher breast tissue density is recognized as a marker for increased breast cancer risk. The study involved a small group of women who received the omega-3 fatty acid, the omega-3 in tandem with a chemo-preventative drug Raloxifene, the drug alone, or no treatment at all. According to the release, at the end of two years, women considered obese (their body mass index — BMI — was greater than 29) showed a reduction in breast tissue density, which the researchers argued reduced their cancer risk. However, this is misleading. This finding is from a small subgroup of obese women within the already-small study. The main finding of the study — which is never even mentioned in the news release — is that the supplement had no impact on reducing high breast density whether taken alone or in tandem with Raloxifene. The release also omitted projected costs and harms of the prescription-only supplement used in the study. The American Cancer Society predicts that 246,660 new cases of invasive breast cancer will be diagnosed in women this year and that more than 40,000 women will die from this disease. Easy actions that women can take to prevent this disease, or at least reduce their risk of getting it, are of almost universal interest to the public. If it is shown that taking a readily available supplement like omega-3 fatty acids will reduce breast cancer risk in obese women, that’s information that will be of wide interest.

### Context: The claim that HIV/AIDS among women is skyrocketing in Austin is not accurate. While black women have consistently been diagnosed with HIV/AIDS at higher rates than other women, HIV/AIDS incidence rates for Travis County women have actually declined for most of the past decade. In 2014, the rate of new HIV diagnoses for black females was 16 per 100,000 black women, up from 12.3 in 2013. However, there was a 27% drop in new HIV diagnoses for black females between 2013 and 2014. The rates of HIV and AIDS among African-American males and females in Travis County have consistently been higher than the rates among Hispanics and whites. Poverty is a key factor contributing to the higher rates of HIV/AIDS among African-American women, as it can result in less access to care and a failure to know one's HIV status. Additionally, stigma, fear, discrimination, homophobia, and negative perceptions about HIV testing can also place African-American women at higher risk. However, it is important to note that the overall incidence rates of HIV/AIDS among women in Travis County have declined over the past decade. The claim made by Austin City Council Member Ora Houston that HIV/AIDS among women is skyrocketing in Austin is not supported by the data.
Claim: HIV/AIDS among women is skyrocketing in Austin.
The claim veracity: false

### Explanation:
label: false
explanation: Houston said HIV/AIDS among women is skyrocketing in Austin. That’s not so. While black women have persistently been diagnosed with HIV/AIDS at higher rates than other women, HIV/AIDS incidence rates for Travis County women declined for most of the past decade.
claim: HIV/AIDS among women is skyrocketing in Austin.
generated_result: Houston said that ""HIV/AIDS among women is skyrocketing in Austin."" We found no evidence to support that. In fact, the rate of new HIV diagnoses for Travis County women has declined for most of the past decade.

### Context: The article discusses the various speculations and rumors surrounding the meaning of the word "covfefe" that President Trump tweeted in May 2017. Some people speculated that it could be a code or an Arabic word, while others claimed it was a Yiddish word. However, the article debunks these claims.

Regarding the Arabic speculation, the article states that Google Translate does not provide any translation for "covfefe" in Arabic. Additionally, a linguist and language instructor fluent in Arabic dialects confirms that the word has nothing to do with the Arabic language. The closest translation for "I will stand up" in Arabic is "sa aqif."

As for the Yiddish speculation, the article mentions a rumor that "covfefe" is a Yiddish word meaning "a futile search" or "a pointless and false quest." However, experts from the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research and New York University's Linguistics Department confirm that "covfefe" is not a Yiddish word. They also state that the legend cited in the rumor is likely made up.

In conclusion, the article dismisses the claims that "covfefe" has any specific meaning in Arabic or Yiddish. It highlights that Google Translate can be unreliable and that the Yiddish experts consulted do not recognize the word. The true meaning of "covfefe" remains unknown, and the article suggests that a Russian connection might be more plausible given Trump's previous use of Yiddish borrowings.
Claim: Covfefe" means something, anything.
The claim veracity: false

### Explanation:
label: false
explanation: “Covfefe” is not a word, nor is it a Nazi, Israeli, or any other type of acronym. It has no meaning. The President clearly mistyped a tweet, which he later deleted.
claim: Covfefe" means something, anything.
generated_result: Covfefe is not Arabic for ‘I will stand up’ and it’s not Yiddish for ‘a futile search.’

### Context: Republican Nancy Mace, who is running for a congressional seat in South Carolina, attacked Joe Biden's choice of Kamala Harris as his vice presidential running mate. Mace claimed in a tweet that Harris "advocated for restoring voting rights for the Boston bomber." However, Harris did not advocate for giving the surviving Boston marathon bomber the right to vote. During her campaign for the presidential nomination, she expressed openness to the idea of allowing all prisoners, including the bomber, to vote, but she did not advocate for it. Harris emphasized that she believes people who have served their sentences and been released should be able to vote. Mace's statement contains an element of truth but ignores critical facts that would give a different impression.
Claim: Nancy Mace Says Kamala Harris “advocated for restoring voting rights for the Boston bomber.”
The claim veracity: false

### Explanation:
label: false
explanation: Harris has not said that she would advocate for giving the surviving Boston Marathon bomber the right to vote, only that she is open to it. Asked if convicted felons in prison such as the Boston Marathon bomber should be allowed to vote, Harris said: “I think we should have that conversation.”     Asked the next day to elaborate, Harris said, “I’m going to think about” whether felons such as the bomber should vote.
claim: Nancy Mace Says Kamala Harris “advocated for restoring voting rights for the Boston bomber.”
generated_result: Mace’s tweet is a misrepresentation of Harris’ position. Harris did not advocate for giving the surviving Boston marathon bomber the right to vote. She said she was open to the idea of allowing all prisoners, including the bomber, to vote.

### Context: Five individuals have been convicted and one has been acquitted in the case related to a meningitis outbreak that occurred in 2012. The outbreak, which sickened nearly 800 people and resulted in the deaths of at least 64 individuals, was attributed to contaminated injections of medical steroids produced by the New England Compounding Center (NECC) in Framingham, Massachusetts. The defendants were among 14 people charged in 2014 following an investigation into the outbreak.

The workers convicted in this case were not accused of producing or sending the contaminated injections that caused the outbreak. Instead, they were charged with sending and approving other contaminated and substandard drugs. Prosecutors argued that the NECC made drugs in unsanitary conditions, sent untested products, and deceived regulators. They claimed that the defendants disregarded patient health and prioritized profits over safety.

Among those found guilty was Gregory Conigliaro, a part owner of the NECC, who was charged with conspiring to defraud the Food and Drug Administration (FDA). Pharmacist Gene Svirskiy was the only defendant convicted of the most serious charge of racketeering. Other defendants, including pharmacist Christopher Leary, were acquitted of some counts but convicted of others.

Pharmacist Joseph Evanosky, who worked in the NECC's clean rooms where the drugs were made, was acquitted of all charges. His attorney stated that Evanosky was an innocent man who should never have been charged.

So far, a total of 11 people charged in the meningitis outbreak investigation have been convicted. Two other pharmacists are scheduled to go to trial next year. In a previous trial, supervisory pharmacist Glenn Chin was sentenced to eight years in prison after being convicted of racketeering and mail fraud. Co-owner Barry Cadden is currently serving a nine-year prison term for his role in the outbreak.

The article notes that the death toll from the outbreak has now surpassed 100, according to federal prosecutors. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) had previously reported 64 deaths as of October 2013.
Claim: 5 convicted in meningitis outbreak case; 1 acquitted.
The claim veracity: true

label: true

Love's father, Stan, who also played in the NBA, had always struggled with the stigma attached to showing weakness, and Love himself had followed the same playbook of not talking about his feelings. The Cavs encouraged Love to see a therapist, and he now receives counseling a few times a month when the team is at home. Love drew courage to go public with his issues after Toronto Raptors All-Star DeMar DeRozan recently acknowledged his own battles with depression. Love believes that creating a better environment for talking about mental health is crucial. His revelations received praise from teammate LeBron James, who tweeted his support. Love ended his essay by encouraging anyone struggling with mental health issues to seek help and reminding them that sharing their struggles is not weird or different, but rather an important step towards healing.

### Context: The article discusses the death of Daniel Best, the Trump administration's senior adviser on drug pricing reform. Best was found "unresponsive" near the garage door exit of a Washington, D.C., apartment building and was pronounced dead at the scene. The cause of his death was initially not disclosed, but two weeks later, the office of Washington, D.C.'s chief medical examiner announced that Best had died of "multiple blunt force injuries" and ruled it as a suicide.

However, internet conspiracy theorists questioned this ruling, suggesting that Best may have been the victim of foul play. They pointed to the pharmaceutical industry's objections to Best's efforts to lower prescription drug costs, President Trump's announcement of a plan to reduce Medicare drug prices, and the fact that Best died of blunt force injuries. Far-right conspiracist websites also questioned the ruling, sarcastically asking how someone could kill themselves by repeatedly hitting themselves with a blunt object.

The article then explains that the assumption that blunt force injuries can only be sustained in a physical attack is fallacious. Forensic pathologists define a blunt force injury as any injury resulting from impact with a blunt object, which can include hammers, baseball bats, fists, and even the interior surfaces of vehicles, among other things. Blunt force injuries can occur in various scenarios, including transportation fatalities, falls from heights, blast injuries, and being struck by objects.

The article concludes by stating that a ruling of suicide is possible if Best sustained self-inflicted blunt force injuries, depending on the circumstances. It quotes Thomas Sporn, M.D., Chief of the Section of Pulmonary and Thoracic Pathology at Duke University Medical Center, who explains that jumping off a building and striking the pavement or darting into traffic could result in blunt force injuries.

In summary, the article discusses the controversy surrounding the death of Daniel Best, who was found dead with multiple blunt force injuries. While the official ruling was suicide, conspiracy theorists and far-right websites questioned this conclusion, suggesting foul play due to Best's role in drug pricing reform. The article clarifies that blunt force injuries can be self-inflicted and occur in various scenarios, supporting the possibility of suicide.
Claim: A medical examiner's conclusion that Health and Human Services drug pricing adviser Daniel Best died of multiple blunt force injuries contradicts the official ruling that he committed suicide.
The claim veracity: false

### Explanation:
label: false
explanation: To date, we aren’t privy to a full account of how Daniel Best sustained his injuries, nor their precise nature, nor any other evidence (such as a suicide note, if one exists) that prompted medical examiners to conclude that he killed himself. But there is clearly nothing contradictory about his having suffered blunt force injuries during the commission of a suicide. Given the facts at hand, there is no reasonable basis for speculation to the contrary.
claim: A medical examiner's conclusion that Health and Human Services drug pricing adviser Daniel Best died of multiple blunt force injuries contradicts the official ruling that he committed suicide.
generated_result: Did a Medical Examiner Rule That a Trump Official Died of ‘Multiple Blunt Force Injuries’?

The article concludes by stating that while McConnell's characterization of the study may be politically charged, the actual study is a public health research project. In summary, the article addresses the claim that the stimulus package includes "$219,000 to study the sex lives of female college freshmen." It provides information about the study, clarifying that it is a public health research project aimed at understanding the health consequences of casual sexual encounters. The article also highlights the defense of the study by its lead researcher and concludes that the claim is not as sensationalized as it may seem.

### Context: The article discusses a study comparing the effectiveness of over-the-counter (OTC) personal sound amplification products (PSAPs) to conventional hearing aids. The cost of the prescription hearing aid used in the study is mentioned as $1,910, while the PSAPs tested ranged in cost from $30 to $350. The study found that hearing aids alone improved speech recognition by 12 percent, while the three most expensive PSAPs (over $300) improved speech recognition by at least 10 percent. However, the least expensive PSAP ($30) actually worsened speech recognition by 11 percent.

The article points out that the news release should have mentioned the potential harms of PSAPs compared to hearing aids. Cheaper PSAPs may not selectively amplify speech, which could potentially worsen hearing loss by amplifying too loud and broad a range of sound. The article also highlights that the study had a small sample size of 42 participants, which may not be representative of the millions of people who struggle with hearing loss. Additionally, the tests were conducted in a simulated, controlled setting with professional assistance, which may not reflect real-world usage where people may not correctly set up or wear a PSAP.

The release is commended for providing information about the availability of both hearing aids through licensed professionals and PSAPs over-the-counter. However, it is noted that comparing alternatives in highly controlled settings may not accurately reflect real-life situations.

Overall, the article suggests that the study's findings comparing PSAPs to hearing aids are surprising and worthy of attention, despite the limitations of the small sample size and controlled methodology. The article does not detect any exaggerated or hyped language in the release.
